As nothing else could match.
enriched.character_situation: Othello is telling Desdemona about the sacred history of the handkerchief she has lost, revealing its magical origins and the dire consequences of losing it. He is testing her reaction while building psychological pressure about the handkerchief's supposed power.

enriched.quote: Madam, my former suit: I do beseech you / That by your virtuous means I may again / Exist, and be a member of his love / Whom I with all the office of my heart
enriched.full_text:
Madam, my former suit: I do beseech you
That by your virtuous means I may again
Exist, and be a member of his love
Whom I with all the office of my heart
Entirely honour: I would not be delay'd.
If my offence be of such mortal kind
That nor my service past, nor present sorrows,
Nor purposed merit in futurity,
Can ransom me into his love again,
But to know so must be my benefit;
So shall I clothe me in a forced content,
And shut myself up in some other course,
To fortune's alms.
enriched.character_situation: Cassio is desperately pleading with Desdemona to help restore him to Othello's favor after his disgrace. He fears his offense may be unforgivable and is prepared to accept his fate if reconciliation proves impossible.

enriched.quote: Alas, thrice-gentle Cassio! / My advocation is not now in tune; / My lord is not my lord; nor should I know him, / Were he in favour as in humour alter'd.
enriched.full_text:
Alas, thrice-gentle Cassio!
My advocation is not now in tune;
My lord is not my lord; nor should I know him,
Were he in favour as in humour alter'd.
So help me every spirit sanctified,
As I have spoken for you all my best
And stood within the blank of his displeasure
For my free speech! you must awhile be patient:
What I can do I will; and more I will
Than for myself I dare: let that suffice you.
enriched.character_situation: Desdemona is explaining to Cassio that she cannot help him right now because Othello has changed dramatically and she herself has fallen out of his favor. She recognizes her husband's transformation but remains committed to helping despite personal risk.

enriched.quote: I prithee, do so. / Something, sure, of state, / Either from Venice, or some unhatch'd practise / Made demonstrable here in Cyprus to him,
enriched.full_text:
I prithee, do so.
Something, sure, of state,
Either from Venice, or some unhatch'd practise
Made demonstrable here in Cyprus to him,
Hath puddled his clear spirit: and in such cases
Men's natures wrangle with inferior things,
Though great ones are their object. 'Tis even so;
For let our finger ache, and it indues
Our other healthful members even to that sense
Of pain: nay, we must think men are not gods,
Nor of them look for such observances
As fit the bridal. Beshrew me much, Emilia,
I was, unhandsome warrior as I am,
Arraigning his unkindness with my soul;
But now I find I had suborn'd the witness,
And he's indicted falsely.
enriched.character_situation: Desdemona is rationalizing Othello's strange behavior to Emilia, convincing herself that affairs of state must be troubling him. She blames herself for being too critical and makes excuses for his treatment of her.

enriched.quote: O Cassio, whence came this? / This is some token from a newer friend: / To the felt absence now I feel a cause: / Is't come to this? Well, well.
enriched.full_text:
O Cassio, whence came this?
This is some token from a newer friend:
To the felt absence now I feel a cause:
Is't come to this? Well, well.
enriched.character_situation: Bianca confronts Cassio about the handkerchief, suspecting it's a gift from another woman. She realizes this explains his recent absence and feels betrayed by what she perceives as evidence of his infidelity.

enriched.quote: Go to, woman! / Throw your vile guesses in the devil's teeth, / From whence you have them. You are jealous now / That this is from some mistress, some remembrance:
enriched.full_text:
Go to, woman!
Throw your vile guesses in the devil's teeth,
From whence you have them. You are jealous now
That this is from some mistress, some remembrance:
No, in good troth, Bianca.
enriched.character_situation: Cassio is dismissively defending himself against Bianca's accusations of infidelity. He's irritated by her jealous suspicions and tries to reassure her that the handkerchief has no romantic significance.

enriched.quote: Naked in bed, Iago, and not mean harm! / It is hypocrisy against the devil: / They that mean virtuously, and yet do so, / The devil their virtue tempts, and they tempt heaven.
enriched.full_text:
Naked in bed, Iago, and not mean harm!
It is hypocrisy against the devil:
They that mean virtuously, and yet do so,
The devil their virtue tempts, and they tempt heaven.
enriched.character_situation: Othello is expressing his tortured logic about Desdemona and Cassio's supposed affair, struggling with the idea that intimate behavior without evil intent is somehow worse than outright sin. His moral reasoning is becoming twisted by jealousy.

enriched.quote: What, / If I had said I had seen him do you wrong? / Or heard him say,--as knaves be such abroad, / Who having, by their own importunate suit,
enriched.full_text:
What,
If I had said I had seen him do you wrong?
Or heard him say,--as knaves be such abroad,
Who having, by their own importunate suit,
Or voluntary dotage of some mistress,
Convinced or supplied them, cannot choose
But they must blab--
enriched.character_situation: Iago is manipulating Othello by planting hypothetical scenarios about Cassio's betrayal. He's carefully introducing the idea that men who have affairs often boast about their conquests, further poisoning Othello's mind.

enriched.quote: Lie with her! lie on her! We say lie on her, when / they belie her. Lie with her! that's fulsome. / --Handkerchief--confessions--handkerchief!--To / confess, and be hanged for his labour;--first, to be
enriched.full_text:
Lie with her! lie on her! We say lie on her, when
they belie her. Lie with her! that's fulsome.
--Handkerchief--confessions--handkerchief!--To
confess, and be hanged for his labour;--first, to be
hanged, and then to confess.--I tremble at it.
Nature would not invest herself in such shadowing
passion without some instruction. It is not words
that shake me thus. Pish! Noses, ears, and lips.
--Is't possible?--Confess--handkerchief!--O devil!--
enriched.character_situation: Othello is having a psychological breakdown, his mind fragmenting under the weight of jealousy and imagined betrayal. His speech becomes incoherent as he obsesses over the handkerchief and visions of Desdemona's supposed infidelity.

enriched.quote: No, forbear; / The lethargy must have his quiet course: / If not, he foams at mouth and by and by / Breaks out to savage madness. Look he stirs:
enriched.full_text:
No, forbear;
The lethargy must have his quiet course:
If not, he foams at mouth and by and by
Breaks out to savage madness. Look he stirs:
Do you withdraw yourself a little while,
He will recover straight: when he is gone,
I would on great occasion speak with you.
How is it, general? have you not hurt your head?
enriched.character_situation: Iago is coolly managing Othello's epileptic fit or breakdown, demonstrating clinical detachment while maintaining his manipulative control. He uses this moment to further his schemes by arranging to speak privately with Cassio.

enriched.quote: Good sir, be a man; / Think every bearded fellow that's but yoked / May draw with you: there's millions now alive / That nightly lie in those unproper beds
enriched.full_text:
Good sir, be a man;
Think every bearded fellow that's but yoked
May draw with you: there's millions now alive
That nightly lie in those unproper beds
Which they dare swear peculiar: your case is better.
O, 'tis the spite of hell, the fiend's arch-mock,
To lip a wanton in a secure couch,
And to suppose her chaste! No, let me know;
And knowing what I am, I know what she shall be.
enriched.character_situation: Iago is manipulating Othello by convincing him that adultery is common and that Othello should accept his wife's supposed infidelity. He's poisoning Othello's mind with cynical generalizations about marriage and women.

enriched.quote: Stand you awhile apart; / Confine yourself but in a patient list. / Whilst you were here o'erwhelmed with your grief-- / A passion most unsuiting such a man--
enriched.full_text:
Stand you awhile apart;
Confine yourself but in a patient list.
Whilst you were here o'erwhelmed with your grief--
A passion most unsuiting such a man--
Cassio came hither: I shifted him away,
And laid good 'scuse upon your ecstasy,
Bade him anon return and here speak with me;
The which he promised. Do but encave yourself,
And mark the fleers, the gibes, and notable scorns,
That dwell in every region of his face;
For I will make him tell the tale anew,
Where, how, how oft, how long ago, and when
He hath, and is again to cope your wife:
I say, but mark his gesture. Marry, patience;
Or I shall say you are all in all in spleen,
And nothing of a man.
enriched.character_situation: Iago is orchestrating his deception by instructing Othello to hide and watch while he manipulates a conversation with Cassio. He's setting up the visual 'proof' that will destroy Othello's faith in Desdemona.

enriched.quote: That's not amiss; / But yet keep time in all. Will you withdraw? / Now will I question Cassio of Bianca, / A housewife that by selling her desires
enriched.full_text:
That's not amiss;
But yet keep time in all. Will you withdraw?
Now will I question Cassio of Bianca,
A housewife that by selling her desires
Buys herself bread and clothes: it is a creature
That dotes on Cassio; as 'tis the strumpet's plague
To beguile many and be beguiled by one:
He, when he hears of her, cannot refrain
From the excess of laughter. Here he comes:
As he shall smile, Othello shall go mad;
And his unbookish jealousy must construe
Poor Cassio's smiles, gestures and light behavior,
Quite in the wrong. How do you now, lieutenant?
enriched.character_situation: Iago is explaining his plan to make Othello misinterpret Cassio's laughter about Bianca as laughter about Desdemona. He's coldly calculating how to drive Othello to madness through deliberate misunderstanding.

enriched.quote: Let the devil and his dam haunt you! What did you / mean by that same handkerchief you gave me even now? / I was a fine fool to take it. I must take out the / work?--A likely piece of work, that you should find
enriched.full_text:
Let the devil and his dam haunt you! What did you
mean by that same handkerchief you gave me even now?
I was a fine fool to take it. I must take out the
work?--A likely piece of work, that you should find
it in your chamber, and not know who left it there!
This is some minx's token, and I must take out the
work? There; give it your hobby-horse: wheresoever
you had it, I'll take out no work on't.
enriched.character_situation: Bianca is angrily confronting Cassio about the handkerchief, suspecting it belongs to another woman. She feels betrayed and used, refusing to be taken for a fool in matters of love.

enriched.quote: Hang her! I do but say what she is: so delicate / with her needle: an admirable musician: O! she / will sing the savageness out of a bear: of so high / and plenteous wit and invention:--
enriched.full_text:
Hang her! I do but say what she is: so delicate
with her needle: an admirable musician: O! she
will sing the savageness out of a bear: of so high
and plenteous wit and invention:--
enriched.character_situation: Othello is speaking about Desdemona's accomplishments while his mind is poisoned with jealousy. His praise is tinged with bitter irony as he's been convinced of her infidelity.

enriched.quote: Ay; you did wish that I would make her turn: / Sir, she can turn, and turn, and yet go on, / And turn again; and she can weep, sir, weep; / And she's obedient, as you say, obedient,
enriched.full_text:
Ay; you did wish that I would make her turn:
Sir, she can turn, and turn, and yet go on,
And turn again; and she can weep, sir, weep;
And she's obedient, as you say, obedient,
Very obedient. Proceed you in your tears.
Concerning this, sir,--O  well-painted passion!--
I am commanded home. Get you away;
I'll send for you anon. Sir, I obey the mandate,
And will return to Venice. Hence, avaunt!
Cassio shall have my place. And, sir, tonight,
I do entreat that we may sup together:
You are welcome, sir, to Cyprus.--Goats and monkeys!
enriched.character_situation: Othello is breaking down publicly, speaking about Desdemona in crude, double-meaning terms while trying to maintain composure before Lodovico. His jealousy has driven him to near-madness.

enriched.quote: Alas, alas! / It is not honesty in me to speak / What I have seen and known. You shall observe him, / And his own courses will denote him so
enriched.full_text:
Alas, alas!
It is not honesty in me to speak
What I have seen and known. You shall observe him,
And his own courses will denote him so
That I may save my speech: do but go after,
And mark how he continues.
enriched.character_situation: Iago is feigning reluctance to speak ill of Othello while actually encouraging others to observe Othello's deteriorating behavior. He's maintaining his facade of loyalty while orchestrating Othello's downfall.

enriched.quote: I durst, my lord, to wager she is honest, / Lay down my soul at stake: if you think other, / Remove your thought; it doth abuse your bosom. / If any wretch have put this in your head,
enriched.full_text:
I durst, my lord, to wager she is honest,
Lay down my soul at stake: if you think other,
Remove your thought; it doth abuse your bosom.
If any wretch have put this in your head,
Let heaven requite it with the serpent's curse!
For, if she be not honest, chaste, and true,
There's no man happy; the purest of their wives
Is foul as slander.
enriched.character_situation: Emilia is passionately defending Desdemona's virtue and honesty, willing to stake her soul on her mistress's innocence. She suspects someone has poisoned Othello's mind against his wife.

enriched.quote: Alas the heavy day! Why do you weep? / Am I the motive of these tears, my lord? / If haply you my father do suspect / An instrument of this your calling back,
enriched.full_text:
Alas the heavy day! Why do you weep?
Am I the motive of these tears, my lord?
If haply you my father do suspect
An instrument of this your calling back,
Lay not your blame on me: If you have lost him,
Why, I have lost him too.
enriched.character_situation: Desdemona is confused and distressed by Othello's strange behavior and tears, wondering if she's somehow the cause. She's trying to understand what has changed in their relationship.

enriched.quote: Had it pleased heaven / To try me with affliction; had they rain'd / All kinds of sores and shames on my bare head. / Steep'd me in poverty to the very lips,
enriched.full_text:
Had it pleased heaven
To try me with affliction; had they rain'd
All kinds of sores and shames on my bare head.
Steep'd me in poverty to the very lips,
Given to captivity me and my utmost hopes,
I should have found in some place of my soul
A drop of patience: but, alas, to make me
A fixed figure for the time of scorn
To point his slow unmoving finger at!
Yet could I bear that too; well, very well:
But there, where I have garner'd up my heart,
Where either I must live, or bear no life;
The fountain from the which my current runs,
Or else dries up; to be discarded thence!
Or keep it as a cistern for foul toads
To knot and gender in! Turn thy complexion there,
Patience, thou young and rose-lipp'd cherubin,--
Ay, there, look grim as hell!
enriched.character_situation: Othello is expressing that he could have endured any physical suffering or public shame, but cannot bear what he believes is Desdemona's betrayal. He's describing the ultimate spiritual and emotional devastation of losing faith in his beloved.

enriched.quote: O, ay; as summer flies are in the shambles, / That quicken even with blowing. O thou weed, / Who art so lovely fair and smell'st so sweet / That the sense aches at thee, would thou hadst
enriched.full_text:
O, ay; as summer flies are in the shambles,
That quicken even with blowing. O thou weed,
Who art so lovely fair and smell'st so sweet
That the sense aches at thee, would thou hadst
ne'er been born!
enriched.character_situation: Othello is confronting Desdemona, consumed by jealousy and believing her to be unfaithful. He sees her beauty as a cruel contradiction to what he believes is her corrupt nature.

enriched.quote: Was this fair paper, this most goodly book, / Made to write 'whore' upon? What committed! / Committed! O thou public commoner! / I should make very forges of my cheeks,
enriched.full_text:
Was this fair paper, this most goodly book,
Made to write 'whore' upon? What committed!
Committed! O thou public commoner!
I should make very forges of my cheeks,
That would to cinders burn up modesty,
Did I but speak thy deeds. What committed!
Heaven stops the nose at it and the moon winks,
The bawdy wind that kisses all it meets
Is hush'd within the hollow mine of earth,
And will not hear it. What committed!
Impudent strumpet!
enriched.character_situation: Othello is berating Desdemona in a jealous rage, believing she has committed adultery. He cannot reconcile her outward beauty and purity with what he believes are her immoral acts.

enriched.quote: No, as I am a Christian: / If to preserve this vessel for my lord / From any other foul unlawful touch / Be not to be a strumpet, I am none.
enriched.full_text:
No, as I am a Christian:
If to preserve this vessel for my lord
From any other foul unlawful touch
Be not to be a strumpet, I am none.
enriched.character_situation: Desdemona is defending her innocence and faithfulness to Othello, desperately trying to convince him of her virtue. She maintains her dignity despite his accusations.

enriched.quote: I cry you mercy, then: / I took you for that cunning whore of Venice / That married with Othello. / You, mistress,
enriched.full_text:
I cry you mercy, then:
I took you for that cunning whore of Venice
That married with Othello.
You, mistress,
That have the office opposite to Saint Peter,
And keep the gate of hell!
You, you, ay, you!
We have done our course; there's money for your pains:
I pray you, turn the key and keep our counsel.
enriched.character_situation: Othello continues his cruel treatment of Desdemona, sarcastically addressing her as if she were a prostitute and Emilia as her keeper. His jealousy has completely distorted his perception of reality.

enriched.quote: I will be hang'd, if some eternal villain, / Some busy and insinuating rogue, / Some cogging, cozening slave, to get some office, / Have not devised this slander; I'll be hang'd else.
enriched.full_text:
I will be hang'd, if some eternal villain,
Some busy and insinuating rogue,
Some cogging, cozening slave, to get some office,
Have not devised this slander; I'll be hang'd else.
enriched.character_situation: Emilia suspects that some villain has planted lies about Desdemona to destroy her reputation. She is outraged by the injustice and seeks to identify the culprit.

enriched.quote: A halter pardon him! and hell gnaw his bones! / Why should he call her whore? who keeps her company? / What place? what time? what form? what likelihood? / The Moor's abused by some most villanous knave,
enriched.full_text:
A halter pardon him! and hell gnaw his bones!
Why should he call her whore? who keeps her company?
What place? what time? what form? what likelihood?
The Moor's abused by some most villanous knave,
Some base notorious knave, some scurvy fellow.
O heaven, that such companions thou'ldst unfold,
And put in every honest hand a whip
To lash the rascals naked through the world
Even from the east to the west!
enriched.character_situation: Emilia is furious about the slander against Desdemona and calls for divine justice against the unknown villain. She passionately defends Desdemona's innocence and demands punishment for the deceiver.

enriched.quote: O good Iago, / What shall I do to win my lord again? / Good friend, go to him; for, by this light of heaven, / I know not how I lost him. Here I kneel:
enriched.full_text:
O good Iago,
What shall I do to win my lord again?
Good friend, go to him; for, by this light of heaven,
I know not how I lost him. Here I kneel:
If e'er my will did trespass 'gainst his love,
Either in discourse of thought or actual deed,
Or that mine eyes, mine ears, or any sense,
Delighted them in any other form;
Or that I do not yet, and ever did.
And ever will--though he do shake me off
To beggarly divorcement--love him dearly,
Comfort forswear me! Unkindness may do much;
And his unkindness may defeat my life,
But never taint my love. I cannot say 'whore:'
It does abhor me now I speak the word;
To do the act that might the addition earn
Not the world's mass of vanity could make me.
enriched.character_situation: Desdemona is heartbroken and confused by Othello's changed behavior toward her. She pleads with Iago for help in understanding how to win back her husband's love, declaring her unwavering devotion.

enriched.quote: 'Tis but so, I warrant. / Hark, how these instruments summon to supper! / The messengers of Venice stay the meat; / Go in, and weep not; all things shall be well.
enriched.full_text:
'Tis but so, I warrant.
Hark, how these instruments summon to supper!
The messengers of Venice stay the meat;
Go in, and weep not; all things shall be well.
How now, Roderigo!
enriched.character_situation: Iago is manipulating the situation, offering false comfort to Desdemona while secretly orchestrating her destruction. He maintains his facade of helpful friend while planning further evil.

enriched.quote: I grant indeed it hath not appeared, and your / suspicion is not without wit and judgment. But, / Roderigo, if thou hast that in thee indeed, which I / have greater reason to believe now than ever, I mean
enriched.full_text:
I grant indeed it hath not appeared, and your
suspicion is not without wit and judgment. But,
Roderigo, if thou hast that in thee indeed, which I
have greater reason to believe now than ever, I mean
purpose, courage and valour, this night show it: if
thou the next night following enjoy not Desdemona,
take me from this world with treachery and devise
engines for my life.
enriched.character_situation: Iago is manipulating Roderigo, acknowledging his concerns while pushing him toward violence against Cassio. He uses false promises about Desdemona to motivate Roderigo to act.

enriched.quote: O, no; he goes into Mauritania and takes away with / him the fair Desdemona, unless his abode be / lingered here by some accident: wherein none can be / so determinate as the removing of Cassio.
enriched.full_text:
O, no; he goes into Mauritania and takes away with
him the fair Desdemona, unless his abode be
lingered here by some accident: wherein none can be
so determinate as the removing of Cassio.
enriched.character_situation: Iago is explaining to Roderigo why Cassio must be eliminated, claiming it's the only way to prevent Othello from taking Desdemona away. He continues his web of lies to achieve his malicious goals.

enriched.quote: Ay, if you dare do yourself a profit and a right. / He sups to-night with a harlotry, and thither will I / go to him: he knows not yet of his horrorable / fortune. If you will watch his going thence, which
enriched.full_text:
Ay, if you dare do yourself a profit and a right.
He sups to-night with a harlotry, and thither will I
go to him: he knows not yet of his horrorable
fortune. If you will watch his going thence, which
I will fashion to fall out between twelve and one,
you may take him at your pleasure: I will be near
to second your attempt, and he shall fall between
us. Come, stand not amazed at it, but go along with
me; I will show you such a necessity in his death
that you shall think yourself bound to put it on
him. It is now high suppertime, and the night grows
to waste: about it.
enriched.character_situation: Iago is manipulating Roderigo into murdering Cassio, orchestrating the timing and logistics of the attack. He coldly calculates how this violence will serve his larger scheme of revenge.

enriched.quote: My mother had a maid call'd Barbara: / She was in love, and he she loved proved mad / And did forsake her: she had a song of 'willow;' / An old thing 'twas, but it express'd her fortune,
enriched.full_text:
My mother had a maid call'd Barbara:
She was in love, and he she loved proved mad
And did forsake her: she had a song of 'willow;'
An old thing 'twas, but it express'd her fortune,
And she died singing it: that song to-night
Will not go from my mind; I have much to do,
But to go hang my head all at one side,
And sing it like poor Barbara. Prithee, dispatch.
enriched.character_situation: Desdemona feels a deep foreboding about her fate and is haunted by memories of her mother's maid who died of heartbreak. She senses her own tragic destiny approaching.

enriched.quote: [Singing]  The poor soul sat sighing by a sycamore tree, / Sing all a green willow: / Her hand on her bosom, her head on her knee, / Sing willow, willow, willow:
enriched.character_situation: Desdemona sings the willow song, unconsciously preparing for her own death while identifying with Barbara's tragic fate. She is distracted and anxious, interrupted by sounds that heighten her fear.

enriched.quote: [Singing]  I call'd my love false love; but what / said he then? / Sing willow, willow, willow: / If I court moe women, you'll couch with moe men!
enriched.full_text:
[Singing]  I call'd my love false love; but what
said he then?
Sing willow, willow, willow:
If I court moe women, you'll couch with moe men!
So, get thee gone; good night Ate eyes do itch;
Doth that bode weeping?
enriched.character_situation: Desdemona continues the willow song, expressing the pain of false love while experiencing physical signs of distress. She senses impending doom through her tears.

enriched.quote: I have heard it said so. O, these men, these men! / Dost thou in conscience think,--tell me, Emilia,-- / That there be women do abuse their husbands / In such gross kind?
enriched.full_text:
I have heard it said so. O, these men, these men!
Dost thou in conscience think,--tell me, Emilia,--
That there be women do abuse their husbands
In such gross kind?
enriched.character_situation: Desdemona expresses innocent disbelief about women's capacity for adultery, revealing her pure nature even as she faces accusations of infidelity. She seeks understanding from Emilia about human nature.

enriched.quote: Yes, a dozen; and as many to the vantage as would / store the world they played for. / But I do think it is their husbands' faults / If wives do fall: say that they slack their duties,
enriched.full_text:
Yes, a dozen; and as many to the vantage as would
store the world they played for.
But I do think it is their husbands' faults
If wives do fall: say that they slack their duties,
And pour our treasures into foreign laps,
Or else break out in peevish jealousies,
Throwing restraint upon us; or say they strike us,
Or scant our former having in despite;
Why, we have galls, and though we have some grace,
Yet have we some revenge. Let husbands know
Their wives have sense like them: they see and smell
And have their palates both for sweet and sour,
As husbands have. What is it that they do
When they change us for others? Is it sport?
I think it is: and doth affection breed it?
I think it doth: is't frailty that thus errs?
It is so too: and have not we affections,
Desires for sport, and frailty, as men have?
Then let them use us well: else let them know,
The ills we do, their ills instruct us so.
enriched.character_situation: Emilia defends women's equality and argues that unfaithful wives are created by neglectful or abusive husbands. She challenges the double standard between men and women regarding fidelity.

enriched.quote: I have rubb'd this young quat almost to the sense, / And he grows angry. Now, whether he kill Cassio, / Or Cassio him, or each do kill the other, / Every way makes my gain: live Roderigo,
enriched.full_text:
I have rubb'd this young quat almost to the sense,
And he grows angry. Now, whether he kill Cassio,
Or Cassio him, or each do kill the other,
Every way makes my gain: live Roderigo,
He calls me to a restitution large
Of gold and jewels that I bobb'd from him,
As gifts to Desdemona;
It must not be: if Cassio do remain,
He hath a daily beauty in his life
That makes me ugly; and, besides, the Moor
May unfold me to him; there stand I in much peril:
No, he must die. But so: I hear him coming.
enriched.character_situation: Iago coldly calculates the outcomes of his manipulation, seeing profit in any result of the violence he has orchestrated. He feels threatened by Cassio's virtue and fears exposure.

enriched.quote: 'Tis he:--O brave Iago, honest and just, / That hast such noble sense of thy friend's wrong! / Thou teachest me. Minion, your dear lies dead, / And your unblest fate hies: strumpet, I come.
enriched.full_text:
'Tis he:--O brave Iago, honest and just,
That hast such noble sense of thy friend's wrong!
Thou teachest me. Minion, your dear lies dead,
And your unblest fate hies: strumpet, I come.
Forth of my heart those charms, thine eyes, are blotted;
Thy bed, lust-stain'd, shall with lust's blood be spotted.
enriched.character_situation: Othello believes he has witnessed proof of Iago's loyalty and Desdemona's guilt, steeling himself for murder. He is consumed by jealous rage and sees himself as an agent of justice.

enriched.quote: [To BIANCA]  What, look you pale? O, bear him out / o' the air. / Stay you, good gentlemen. Look you pale, mistress? / Do you perceive the gastness of her eye?
enriched.full_text:
[To BIANCA]  What, look you pale? O, bear him out
o' the air.
Stay you, good gentlemen. Look you pale, mistress?
Do you perceive the gastness of her eye?
Nay, if you stare, we shall hear more anon.
Behold her well; I pray you, look upon her:
Do you see, gentlemen? nay, guiltiness will speak,
Though tongues were out of use.
enriched.character_situation: Iago manipulates the scene after Cassio's wounding, directing suspicion toward Bianca while maintaining his facade of helpful investigation. He orchestrates the narrative to serve his purposes.

enriched.quote: It is the cause, it is the cause, my soul,-- / Let me not name it to you, you chaste stars!-- / It is the cause. Yet I'll not shed her blood; / Nor scar that whiter skin of hers than snow,
enriched.full_text:
It is the cause, it is the cause, my soul,--
Let me not name it to you, you chaste stars!--
It is the cause. Yet I'll not shed her blood;
Nor scar that whiter skin of hers than snow,
And smooth as monumental alabaster.
Yet she must die, else she'll betray more men.
Put out the light, and then put out the light:
If I quench thee, thou flaming minister,
I can again thy former light restore,
Should I repent me: but once put out thy light,
Thou cunning'st pattern of excelling nature,
I know not where is that Promethean heat
That can thy light relume. When I have pluck'd the rose,
I cannot give it vital growth again.
It must needs wither: I'll smell it on the tree.
Ah balmy breath, that dost almost persuade
Justice to break her sword! One more, one more.
Be thus when thou art dead, and I will kill thee,
And love thee after. One more, and this the last:
So sweet was ne'er so fatal. I must weep,
But they are cruel tears: this sorrow's heavenly;
It strikes where it doth love. She wakes.
enriched.character_situation: Othello approaches the sleeping Desdemona, convinced he must kill her to prevent her from betraying other men. He struggles between his love for her beauty and his belief that justice demands her death.

enriched.quote: Yes: 'tis Emilia. By and by. She's dead. / 'Tis like she comes to speak of Cassio's death.-- / The noise was here. Ha! no more moving? / Still as the grave. Shall she come in? were't good?--
enriched.full_text:
Yes: 'tis Emilia. By and by. She's dead.
'Tis like she comes to speak of Cassio's death.--
The noise was here. Ha! no more moving?
Still as the grave. Shall she come in? were't good?--
I think she stirs again:--no. What's best to do?
If she come in, she'll sure speak to my wife:
My wife! my wife! what wife? I have no wife.
O insupportable! O heavy hour!
Methinks it should be now a huge eclipse
Of sun and moon, and that the affrighted globe
Should yawn at alteration.
enriched.character_situation: Othello has just murdered Desdemona and is confronting the reality of his deed as Emilia knocks at the door. He is torn between concealing his crime and facing the consequences, recognizing the cosmic horror of what he has done.

enriched.quote: I had forgot thee: O, come in, Emilia; / Soft; by and by. Let me the curtains draw. / Where art thou? / What's the matter with thee now?
enriched.full_text:
I had forgot thee: O, come in, Emilia;
Soft; by and by. Let me the curtains draw.
Where art thou?
What's the matter with thee now?
enriched.character_situation: Othello is attempting to compose himself and hide evidence of his crime as he admits Emilia into the chamber. He is trying to maintain control while concealing Desdemona's body.

enriched.quote: Disprove this villain, if thou be'st a man: / He says thou told'st him that his wife was false: / I know thou didst not, thou'rt not such a villain: / Speak, for my heart is full.
enriched.full_text:
Disprove this villain, if thou be'st a man:
He says thou told'st him that his wife was false:
I know thou didst not, thou'rt not such a villain:
Speak, for my heart is full.
enriched.character_situation: Emilia is desperately pleading for someone to contradict Iago's lies about Desdemona's infidelity. She is overwhelmed with grief and urgency to defend her murdered mistress's honor.

enriched.quote: [Rising]  O, she was foul! / I scarce did know you, uncle: there lies your niece, / Whose breath, indeed, these hands have newly stopp'd: / I know this act shows horrible and grim.
enriched.full_text:
[Rising]  O, she was foul!
I scarce did know you, uncle: there lies your niece,
Whose breath, indeed, these hands have newly stopp'd:
I know this act shows horrible and grim.
enriched.character_situation: Othello is confessing to the murder while still believing in Desdemona's guilt. He acknowledges the horror of his act but maintains it was justified by her perceived betrayal.

enriched.quote: 'Tis pitiful; but yet Iago knows / That she with Cassio hath the act of shame / A thousand times committed; Cassio confess'd it: / And she did gratify his amorous works
enriched.full_text:
'Tis pitiful; but yet Iago knows
That she with Cassio hath the act of shame
A thousand times committed; Cassio confess'd it:
And she did gratify his amorous works
With that recognizance and pledge of love
Which I first gave her; I saw it in his hand:
It was a handkerchief, an antique token
My father gave my mother.
enriched.character_situation: Othello is explaining his motivation for the murder, recounting Iago's false evidence including the handkerchief. He remains convinced of Desdemona's infidelity despite the tragic circumstances.

enriched.quote: 'Twill out, 'twill out: I peace! / No, I will speak as liberal as the north: / Let heaven and men and devils, let them all, / All, all, cry shame against me, yet I'll speak.
enriched.full_text:
'Twill out, 'twill out: I peace!
No, I will speak as liberal as the north:
Let heaven and men and devils, let them all,
All, all, cry shame against me, yet I'll speak.
enriched.character_situation: Emilia has discovered the truth about Iago's manipulation and is determined to expose it regardless of personal consequences. She chooses truth over safety or loyalty to her husband.

enriched.quote: What did thy song bode, lady? / Hark, canst thou hear me? I will play the swan. / And die in music. / Willow, willow, willow,--
enriched.full_text:
What did thy song bode, lady?
Hark, canst thou hear me? I will play the swan.
And die in music.
Willow, willow, willow,--
Moor, she was chaste; she loved thee, cruel Moor;
So come my soul to bliss, as I speak true;
So speaking as I think, I die, I die.
enriched.character_situation: Emilia is dying after being stabbed by Iago, using her final moments to vindicate Desdemona's innocence. She faces death with courage, determined to speak the truth.

enriched.quote: Behold, I have a weapon; / A better never did itself sustain / Upon a soldier's thigh: I have seen the day, / That, with this little arm and this good sword,
enriched.full_text:
Behold, I have a weapon;
A better never did itself sustain
Upon a soldier's thigh: I have seen the day,
That, with this little arm and this good sword,
I have made my way through more impediments
Than twenty times your stop: but, O vain boast!
Who can control his fate? 'tis not so now.
Be not afraid, though you do see me weapon'd;
Here is my journey's end, here is my butt,
And very sea-mark of my utmost sail.
Do you go back dismay'd? 'tis a lost fear;
Man but a rush against Othello's breast,
And he retires. Where should Othello go?
Now, how dost thou look now? O ill-starr'd wench!
Pale as thy smock! when we shall meet at compt,
This look of thine will hurl my soul from heaven,
And fiends will snatch at it. Cold, cold, my girl!
Even like thy chastity. O cursed slave!
Whip me, ye devils,
From the possession of this heavenly sight!
Blow me about in winds! roast me in sulphur!
Wash me in steep-down gulfs of liquid fire!
O Desdemona! Desdemona! dead!
Oh! Oh! Oh!
enriched.character_situation: Othello, now knowing the truth about Desdemona's innocence and his own manipulation, contemplates suicide. He is overwhelmed by guilt and the realization of his terrible mistake.

enriched.quote: Sir, you shall understand what hath befall'n, / Which, as I think, you know not. Here is a letter / Found in the pocket of the slain Roderigo; / And here another: the one of them imports
enriched.full_text:
Sir, you shall understand what hath befall'n,
Which, as I think, you know not. Here is a letter
Found in the pocket of the slain Roderigo;
And here another: the one of them imports
The death of Cassio to be undertook
By Roderigo.
enriched.character_situation: Lodovico is explaining the conspiracy to those present, revealing evidence found on Roderigo's body that exposes Iago's plot. He serves as the voice of official justice and truth.

enriched.quote: You must forsake this room, and go with us: / Your power and your command is taken off, / And Cassio rules in Cyprus. For this slave, / If there be any cunning cruelty
enriched.full_text:
You must forsake this room, and go with us:
Your power and your command is taken off,
And Cassio rules in Cyprus. For this slave,
If there be any cunning cruelty
That can torment him much and hold him long,
It shall be his. You shall close prisoner rest,
Till that the nature of your fault be known
To the Venetian state. Come, bring him away.
enriched.character_situation: Lodovico is pronouncing judgment and restoring order after the tragedy. He represents the state's authority in dispensing justice and punishment to the surviving conspirators.

enriched.quote: Soft you; a word or two before you go. / I have done the state some service, and they know't. / No more of that. I pray you, in your letters, / When you shall these unlucky deeds relate,
enriched.full_text:
Soft you; a word or two before you go.
I have done the state some service, and they know't.
No more of that. I pray you, in your letters,
When you shall these unlucky deeds relate,
Speak of me as I am; nothing extenuate,
Nor set down aught in malice: then must you speak
Of one that loved not wisely but too well;
Of one not easily jealous, but being wrought
Perplex'd in the extreme; of one whose hand,
Like the base Indian, threw a pearl away
Richer than all his tribe; of one whose subdued eyes,
Albeit unused to the melting mood,
Drop tears as fast as the Arabian trees
Their medicinal gum. Set you down this;
And say besides, that in Aleppo once,
Where a malignant and a turban'd Turk
Beat a Venetian and traduced the state,
I took by the throat the circumcised dog,
And smote him, thus.
enriched.character_situation: Othello, having murdered Desdemona in jealous rage, is about to kill himself and wants to control how history remembers him. He seeks to justify his actions while acknowledging his tragic error in destroying what he loved most.

enriched.quote: Meantime we shall express our darker purpose. / Give me the map there. Know that we have divided / In three our kingdom: and 'tis our fast intent / To shake all cares and business from our age;
enriched.full_text:
Meantime we shall express our darker purpose.
Give me the map there. Know that we have divided
In three our kingdom: and 'tis our fast intent
To shake all cares and business from our age;
Conferring them on younger strengths, while we
Unburthen'd crawl toward death. Our son of Cornwall,
And you, our no less loving son of Albany,
We have this hour a constant will to publish
Our daughters' several dowers, that future strife
May be prevented now. The princes, France and Burgundy,
Great rivals in our youngest daughter's love,
Long in our court have made their amorous sojourn,
And here are to be answer'd. Tell me, my daughters,--
Since now we will divest us both of rule,
Interest of territory, cares of state,--
Which of you shall we say doth love us most?
That we our largest bounty may extend
Where nature doth with merit challenge. Goneril,
Our eldest-born, speak first.
enriched.character_situation: King Lear is announcing his abdication plan and dividing his kingdom among his three daughters based on their public declarations of love. He believes he is wisely transitioning power while securing his legacy and comfort in old age.

enriched.quote: Sir, I am made / Of the self-same metal that my sister is, / And prize me at her worth. In my true heart / I find she names my very deed of love;
enriched.full_text:
Sir, I am made
Of the self-same metal that my sister is,
And prize me at her worth. In my true heart
I find she names my very deed of love;
Only she comes too short: that I profess
Myself an enemy to all other joys,
Which the most precious square of sense possesses;
And find I am alone felicitate
In your dear highness' love.
enriched.character_situation: Regan is competing with her sister Goneril for the largest share of their father's kingdom by flattering him with exaggerated declarations of love. She strategically claims to love him even more than Goneril does.

enriched.quote: To thee and thine hereditary ever / Remain this ample third of our fair kingdom; / No less in space, validity, and pleasure, / Than that conferr'd on Goneril. Now, our joy,
enriched.full_text:
To thee and thine hereditary ever
Remain this ample third of our fair kingdom;
No less in space, validity, and pleasure,
Than that conferr'd on Goneril. Now, our joy,
Although the last, not least; to whose young love
The vines of France and milk of Burgundy
Strive to be interess'd; what can you say to draw
A third more opulent than your sisters? Speak.
enriched.character_situation: Lear is pleased with Regan's flattery and awards her an equal share of the kingdom as Goneril received. He now turns expectantly to his youngest and most beloved daughter Cordelia, anticipating she will outdo her sisters' praise.

enriched.quote: Good my lord, / You have begot me, bred me, loved me: I / Return those duties back as are right fit, / Obey you, love you, and most honour you.
enriched.full_text:
Good my lord,
You have begot me, bred me, loved me: I
Return those duties back as are right fit,
Obey you, love you, and most honour you.
Why have my sisters husbands, if they say
They love you all? Haply, when I shall wed,
That lord whose hand must take my plight shall carry
Half my love with him, half my care and duty:
Sure, I shall never marry like my sisters,
To love my father all.
enriched.character_situation: Cordelia refuses to participate in the false flattery contest, instead speaking honestly about the natural bounds of filial duty and love. She risks her father's displeasure by challenging the premise of his test.

enriched.quote: Let it be so; thy truth, then, be thy dower: / For, by the sacred radiance of the sun, / The mysteries of Hecate, and the night; / By all the operation of the orbs
enriched.full_text:
Let it be so; thy truth, then, be thy dower:
For, by the sacred radiance of the sun,
The mysteries of Hecate, and the night;
By all the operation of the orbs
From whom we do exist, and cease to be;
Here I disclaim all my paternal care,
Propinquity and property of blood,
And as a stranger to my heart and me
Hold thee, from this, for ever. The barbarous Scythian,
Or he that makes his generation messes
To gorge his appetite, shall to my bosom
Be as well neighbour'd, pitied, and relieved,
As thou my sometime daughter.
enriched.character_situation: Lear is shocked and enraged by Cordelia's refusal to flatter him, interpreting her honesty as ingratitude and defiance. He disowns his most beloved daughter in a fit of wounded pride and anger.

enriched.quote: Peace, Kent! / Come not between the dragon and his wrath. / I loved her most, and thought to set my rest / On her kind nursery. Hence, and avoid my sight!
enriched.full_text:
Peace, Kent!
Come not between the dragon and his wrath.
I loved her most, and thought to set my rest
On her kind nursery. Hence, and avoid my sight!
So be my grave my peace, as here I give
Her father's heart from her! Call France; who stirs?
Call Burgundy. Cornwall and Albany,
With my two daughters' dowers digest this third:
Let pride, which she calls plainness, marry her.
I do invest you jointly with my power,
Pre-eminence, and all the large effects
That troop with majesty. Ourself, by monthly course,
With reservation of an hundred knights,
By you to be sustain'd, shall our abode
Make with you by due turns. Only we still retain
The name, and all the additions to a king;
The sway, revenue, execution of the rest,
Beloved sons, be yours: which to confirm,
This coronet part betwixt you.
enriched.character_situation: Lear continues his rage, warning Kent not to interfere while revealing his deep hurt that Cordelia, whom he loved most, has seemingly betrayed his expectations. He hastily redistributes power and makes arrangements for his retirement.

enriched.quote: Let it fall rather, though the fork invade / The region of my heart: be Kent unmannerly, / When Lear is mad. What wilt thou do, old man? / Think'st thou that duty shall have dread to speak,
enriched.full_text:
Let it fall rather, though the fork invade
The region of my heart: be Kent unmannerly,
When Lear is mad. What wilt thou do, old man?
Think'st thou that duty shall have dread to speak,
When power to flattery bows? To plainness honour's bound,
When majesty stoops to folly. Reverse thy doom;
And, in thy best consideration, cheque
This hideous rashness: answer my life my judgment,
Thy youngest daughter does not love thee least;
Nor are those empty-hearted whose low sound
Reverbs no hollowness.
enriched.character_situation: Kent risks his life and position to challenge Lear's rash decision, arguing that duty requires him to speak truth to power even when the king is acting foolishly. He defends Cordelia's honesty and warns against the dangerous rashness of Lear's actions.

enriched.quote: Hear me, recreant! / On thine allegiance, hear me! / Since thou hast sought to make us break our vow, / Which we durst never yet, and with strain'd pride
enriched.full_text:
Hear me, recreant!
On thine allegiance, hear me!
Since thou hast sought to make us break our vow,
Which we durst never yet, and with strain'd pride
To come between our sentence and our power,
Which nor our nature nor our place can bear,
Our potency made good, take thy reward.
Five days we do allot thee, for provision
To shield thee from diseases of the world;
And on the sixth to turn thy hated back
Upon our kingdom: if, on the tenth day following,
Thy banish'd trunk be found in our dominions,
The moment is thy death. Away! by Jupiter,
This shall not be revoked.
enriched.character_situation: Lear is further enraged by Kent's challenge to his authority and banishes his most loyal servant. He sees Kent's intervention as treason and an unforgivable breach of the natural order that demands subjects obey their king without question.

enriched.quote: Fare thee well, king: sith thus thou wilt appear, / Freedom lives hence, and banishment is here. / The gods to their dear shelter take thee, maid, / That justly think'st, and hast most rightly said!
enriched.full_text:
Fare thee well, king: sith thus thou wilt appear,
Freedom lives hence, and banishment is here.
The gods to their dear shelter take thee, maid,
That justly think'st, and hast most rightly said!
And your large speeches may your deeds approve,
That good effects may spring from words of love.
Thus Kent, O princes, bids you all adieu;
He'll shape his old course in a country new.
enriched.character_situation: Kent accepts his banishment with dignity, blessing Cordelia for her honesty and warning Goneril and Regan that their words must be matched by deeds. He maintains his moral authority even in exile, suggesting he will continue to serve truth in a new land.

enriched.quote: Then leave her, sir; for, by the power that made me, / I tell you all her wealth. / For you, great king, / I would not from your love make such a stray,
enriched.full_text:
Then leave her, sir; for, by the power that made me,
I tell you all her wealth.
For you, great king,
I would not from your love make such a stray,
To match you where I hate; therefore beseech you
To avert your liking a more worthier way
Than on a wretch whom nature is ashamed
Almost to acknowledge hers.
enriched.character_situation: King Lear is furiously disowning his daughter Cordelia, telling the King of France to abandon his suit for her hand. He declares her worthless and shameful, unworthy of France's love.

enriched.quote: This is most strange, / That she, that even but now was your best object, / The argument of your praise, balm of your age, / Most best, most dearest, should in this trice of time
enriched.full_text:
This is most strange,
That she, that even but now was your best object,
The argument of your praise, balm of your age,
Most best, most dearest, should in this trice of time
Commit a thing so monstrous, to dismantle
So many folds of favour. Sure, her offence
Must be of such unnatural degree,
That monsters it, or your fore-vouch'd affection
Fall'n into taint: which to believe of her,
Must be a faith that reason without miracle
Could never plant in me.
enriched.character_situation: The King of France is bewildered by Lear's sudden rejection of Cordelia, who was just moments before his most beloved daughter. He questions whether such a dramatic reversal could be possible.

enriched.quote: I yet beseech your majesty,-- / If for I want that glib and oily art, / To speak and purpose not; since what I well intend, / I'll do't before I speak,--that you make known
enriched.full_text:
I yet beseech your majesty,--
If for I want that glib and oily art,
To speak and purpose not; since what I well intend,
I'll do't before I speak,--that you make known
It is no vicious blot, murder, or foulness,
No unchaste action, or dishonour'd step,
That hath deprived me of your grace and favour;
But even for want of that for which I am richer,
A still-soliciting eye, and such a tongue
As I am glad I have not, though not to have it
Hath lost me in your liking.
enriched.character_situation: Cordelia desperately tries to clear her name before her father, explaining that her only fault is lacking the false flattery that her sisters possess. She maintains her integrity while pleading for understanding.

enriched.quote: Fairest Cordelia, that art most rich, being poor; / Most choice, forsaken; and most loved, despised! / Thee and thy virtues here I seize upon: / Be it lawful I take up what's cast away.
enriched.full_text:
Fairest Cordelia, that art most rich, being poor;
Most choice, forsaken; and most loved, despised!
Thee and thy virtues here I seize upon:
Be it lawful I take up what's cast away.
Gods, gods! 'tis strange that from their cold'st neglect
My love should kindle to inflamed respect.
Thy dowerless daughter, king, thrown to my chance,
Is queen of us, of ours, and our fair France:
Not all the dukes of waterish Burgundy
Can buy this unprized precious maid of me.
Bid them farewell, Cordelia, though unkind:
Thou losest here, a better where to find.
enriched.character_situation: The King of France recognizes Cordelia's true worth despite her father's rejection and decides to marry her. He sees her virtue where others see only loss of fortune and status.

enriched.quote: The jewels of our father, with wash'd eyes / Cordelia leaves you: I know you what you are; / And like a sister am most loath to call / Your faults as they are named. Use well our father:
enriched.full_text:
The jewels of our father, with wash'd eyes
Cordelia leaves you: I know you what you are;
And like a sister am most loath to call
Your faults as they are named. Use well our father:
To your professed bosoms I commit him
But yet, alas, stood I within his grace,
I would prefer him to a better place.
So, farewell to you both.
enriched.character_situation: Cordelia is taking her final leave, addressing her sisters with restrained criticism while expressing concern for her father's welfare. She knows her sisters' true nature but speaks with dignity.

enriched.quote: Thou, nature, art my goddess; to thy law / My services are bound. Wherefore should I / Stand in the plague of custom, and permit / The curiosity of nations to deprive me,
enriched.full_text:
Thou, nature, art my goddess; to thy law
My services are bound. Wherefore should I
Stand in the plague of custom, and permit
The curiosity of nations to deprive me,
For that I am some twelve or fourteen moon-shines
Lag of a brother? Why bastard? wherefore base?
When my dimensions are as well compact,
My mind as generous, and my shape as true,
As honest madam's issue? Why brand they us
With base? with baseness? bastardy? base, base?
Who, in the lusty stealth of nature, take
More composition and fierce quality
Than doth, within a dull, stale, tired bed,
Go to the creating a whole tribe of fops,
Got 'tween asleep and wake? Well, then,
Legitimate Edgar, I must have your land:
Our father's love is to the bastard Edmund
As to the legitimate: fine word,--legitimate!
Well, my legitimate, if this letter speed,
And my invention thrive, Edmund the base
Shall top the legitimate. I grow; I prosper:
Now, gods, stand up for bastards!
enriched.character_situation: Edmund rails against the social conventions that make him inferior due to his illegitimate birth. He rejects societal laws in favor of natural law and plots to usurp his legitimate brother Edgar's inheritance.

enriched.quote: No? What needed, then, that terrible dispatch of / it into your pocket? the quality of nothing hath / not such need to hide itself. Let's see: come, / if it be nothing, I shall not need spectacles.
enriched.full_text:
No? What needed, then, that terrible dispatch of
it into your pocket? the quality of nothing hath
not such need to hide itself. Let's see: come,
if it be nothing, I shall not need spectacles.
enriched.character_situation: Gloucester is suspicious of Edmund's attempt to hide a letter and demands to see it. He's being drawn into Edmund's deceptive plot against Edgar.

enriched.quote: [Reads]  'This policy and reverence of age makes / the world bitter to the best of our times; keeps / our fortunes from us till our oldness cannot relish / them. I begin to find an idle and fond bondage
enriched.full_text:
[Reads]  'This policy and reverence of age makes
the world bitter to the best of our times; keeps
our fortunes from us till our oldness cannot relish
them. I begin to find an idle and fond bondage
in the oppression of aged tyranny; who sways, not
as it hath power, but as it is suffered. Come to
me, that of this I may speak more. If our father
would sleep till I waked him, you should half his
revenue for ever, and live the beloved of your
brother,	EDGAR.'
Hum--conspiracy!--'Sleep till I waked him,--you
should enjoy half his revenue,'--My son Edgar!
Had he a hand to write this? a heart and brain
to breed it in?--When came this to you? who
brought it?
enriched.character_situation: Gloucester reads Edmund's forged letter supposedly from Edgar, expressing shock and disbelief that his legitimate son could plot against him. He's being completely deceived by Edmund's manipulation.

enriched.quote: I do not well know, my lord. If it shall please / you to suspend your indignation against my / brother till you can derive from him better / testimony of his intent, you shall run a certain
enriched.full_text:
I do not well know, my lord. If it shall please
you to suspend your indignation against my
brother till you can derive from him better
testimony of his intent, you shall run a certain
course; where, if you violently proceed against
him, mistaking his purpose, it would make a great
gap in your own honour, and shake in pieces the
heart of his obedience. I dare pawn down my life
for him, that he hath wrote this to feel my
affection to your honour, and to no further
pretence of danger.
enriched.character_situation: Edmund is masterfully manipulating his father Gloucester, pretending to defend Edgar while actually deepening suspicion against him. He presents himself as the loyal son trying to prevent rash action.

enriched.quote: If your honour judge it meet, I will place you / where you shall hear us confer of this, and by an / auricular assurance have your satisfaction; and / that without any further delay than this very evening.
enriched.full_text:
If your honour judge it meet, I will place you
where you shall hear us confer of this, and by an
auricular assurance have your satisfaction; and
that without any further delay than this very evening.
enriched.character_situation: Edmund continues his manipulation by offering to arrange for Gloucester to overhear a staged conversation with Edgar. He's setting the final trap to destroy his brother's reputation.

enriched.quote: These late eclipses in the sun and moon portend / no good to us: though the wisdom of nature can / reason it thus and thus, yet nature finds itself / scourged by the sequent effects: love cools,
enriched.full_text:
These late eclipses in the sun and moon portend
no good to us: though the wisdom of nature can
reason it thus and thus, yet nature finds itself
scourged by the sequent effects: love cools,
friendship falls off, brothers divide: in
cities, mutinies; in countries, discord; in
palaces, treason; and the bond cracked 'twixt son
and father. This villain of mine comes under the
prediction; there's son against father: the king
falls from bias of nature; there's father against
child. We have seen the best of our time:
machinations, hollowness, treachery, and all
ruinous disorders, follow us disquietly to our
graves. Find out this villain, Edmund; it shall
lose thee nothing; do it carefully. And the
noble and true-hearted Kent banished! his
offence, honesty! 'Tis strange.
enriched.character_situation: Gloucester is disturbed by recent celestial omens and the breakdown of natural order around him. He's witnessing family betrayals and political chaos while being manipulated by Edmund to suspect Edgar.

enriched.quote: This is the excellent foppery of the world, that, / when we are sick in fortune,--often the surfeit / of our own behavior,--we make guilty of our / disasters the sun, the moon, and the stars: as
enriched.full_text:
This is the excellent foppery of the world, that,
when we are sick in fortune,--often the surfeit
of our own behavior,--we make guilty of our
disasters the sun, the moon, and the stars: as
if we were villains by necessity; fools by
heavenly compulsion; knaves, thieves, and
treachers, by spherical predominance; drunkards,
liars, and adulterers, by an enforced obedience of
planetary influence; and all that we are evil in,
by a divine thrusting on: an admirable evasion
of whoremaster man, to lay his goatish
disposition to the charge of a star! My
father compounded with my mother under the
dragon's tail; and my nativity was under Ursa
major; so that it follows, I am rough and
lecherous. Tut, I should have been that I am,
had the maidenliest star in the firmament
twinkled on my bastardizing. Edgar--
And pat he comes like the catastrophe of the old
comedy: my cue is villanous melancholy, with a
sigh like Tom o' Bedlam. O, these eclipses do
portend these divisions! fa, sol, la, mi.
enriched.character_situation: Edmund mockingly dismisses his father's superstitious beliefs about celestial influence on human behavior. He's preparing to manipulate Edgar while asserting his own agency in his villainous schemes.

enriched.quote: By day and night he wrongs me; every hour / He flashes into one gross crime or other, / That sets us all at odds: I'll not endure it: / His knights grow riotous, and himself upbraids us
enriched.full_text:
By day and night he wrongs me; every hour
He flashes into one gross crime or other,
That sets us all at odds: I'll not endure it:
His knights grow riotous, and himself upbraids us
On every trifle. When he returns from hunting,
I will not speak with him; say I am sick:
If you come slack of former services,
You shall do well; the fault of it I'll answer.
enriched.character_situation: Goneril is frustrated with her father's demanding behavior and the chaos his knights bring to her household. She's planning to confront him by withdrawing proper service and respect.

enriched.quote: Put on what weary negligence you please, / You and your fellows; I'll have it come to question: / If he dislike it, let him to our sister, / Whose mind and mine, I know, in that are one,
enriched.full_text:
Put on what weary negligence you please,
You and your fellows; I'll have it come to question:
If he dislike it, let him to our sister,
Whose mind and mine, I know, in that are one,
Not to be over-ruled. Idle old man,
That still would manage those authorities
That he hath given away! Now, by my life,
Old fools are babes again; and must be used
With cheques as flatteries,--when they are seen abused.
Remember what I tell you.
enriched.character_situation: Goneril is instructing her servants to treat Lear with deliberate negligence to force a confrontation. She's asserting control over her domain while dismissing her father as a powerless old man.

enriched.quote: If but as well I other accents borrow, / That can my speech defuse, my good intent / May carry through itself to that full issue / For which I razed my likeness. Now, banish'd Kent,
enriched.full_text:
If but as well I other accents borrow,
That can my speech defuse, my good intent
May carry through itself to that full issue
For which I razed my likeness. Now, banish'd Kent,
If thou canst serve where thou dost stand condemn'd,
So may it come, thy master, whom thou lovest,
Shall find thee full of labours.
enriched.character_situation: Kent is planning to disguise himself to continue serving Lear despite his banishment. He's determined to remain loyal and helpful to his beloved master through deception.

enriched.quote: I do profess to be no less than I seem; to serve / him truly that will put me in trust: to love him / that is honest; to converse with him that is wise, / and says little; to fear judgment; to fight when I
enriched.full_text:
I do profess to be no less than I seem; to serve
him truly that will put me in trust: to love him
that is honest; to converse with him that is wise,
and says little; to fear judgment; to fight when I
cannot choose; and to eat no fish.
enriched.character_situation: Kent, in disguise, is presenting himself to Lear as an honest servant seeking employment. He's establishing his credentials through a code of simple virtues and integrity.

enriched.quote: Follow me; thou shalt serve me: if I like thee no / worse after dinner, I will not part from thee yet. / Dinner, ho, dinner! Where's my knave? my fool? / Go you, and call my fool hither.
enriched.full_text:
Follow me; thou shalt serve me: if I like thee no
worse after dinner, I will not part from thee yet.
Dinner, ho, dinner! Where's my knave? my fool?
Go you, and call my fool hither.
You, you, sirrah, where's my daughter?
enriched.character_situation: Lear is pleased with Kent's disguised presentation and immediately hires him as a servant. He's showing his impulsive nature while calling for his Fool and daughter.

enriched.quote: My lord, I know not what the matter is; but, to my / judgment, your highness is not entertained with that / ceremonious affection as you were wont; there's a / great abatement of kindness appears as well in the
enriched.full_text:
My lord, I know not what the matter is; but, to my
judgment, your highness is not entertained with that
ceremonious affection as you were wont; there's a
great abatement of kindness appears as well in the
general dependants as in the duke himself also and
your daughter.
enriched.character_situation: The Knight is diplomatically informing Lear that he's being treated with less respect than usual by Goneril's household. He's serving as a messenger of unwelcome news about changing family dynamics.

enriched.quote: Mark it, nuncle: / Have more than thou showest, / Speak less than thou knowest, / Lend less than thou owest,
enriched.full_text:
Mark it, nuncle:
Have more than thou showest,
Speak less than thou knowest,
Lend less than thou owest,
Ride more than thou goest,
Learn more than thou trowest,
Set less than thou throwest;
Leave thy drink and thy whore,
And keep in-a-door,
And thou shalt have more
Than two tens to a score.
enriched.character_situation: The Fool is offering Lear practical wisdom through riddling advice about prudent behavior and self-preservation. He's trying to guide his master through wit and paradox after Lear's foolish abdication.

enriched.quote: That lord that counsell'd thee / To give away thy land, / Come place him here by me, / Do thou for him stand:
enriched.full_text:
That lord that counsell'd thee
To give away thy land,
Come place him here by me,
Do thou for him stand:
The sweet and bitter fool
Will presently appear;
The one in motley here,
The other found out there.
enriched.character_situation: The Fool is directly criticizing whoever advised Lear to give away his kingdom, suggesting that both the advisor and Lear himself are fools. He's using humor to deliver harsh truths about Lear's mistake.

enriched.quote: No, faith, lords and great men will not let me; if / I had a monopoly out, they would have part on't: / and ladies too, they will not let me have all fool / to myself; they'll be snatching. Give me an egg,
enriched.full_text:
No, faith, lords and great men will not let me; if
I had a monopoly out, they would have part on't:
and ladies too, they will not let me have all fool
to myself; they'll be snatching. Give me an egg,
nuncle, and I'll give thee two crowns.
enriched.character_situation: The Fool is making witty observations about how folly is shared among all social classes, not just professional fools. He uses his role to offer coded wisdom to Lear through jest and riddles.

enriched.quote: Why, after I have cut the egg i' the middle, and eat / up the meat, the two crowns of the egg. When thou / clovest thy crown i' the middle, and gavest away / both parts, thou borest thy ass on thy back o'er
enriched.full_text:
Why, after I have cut the egg i' the middle, and eat
up the meat, the two crowns of the egg. When thou
clovest thy crown i' the middle, and gavest away
both parts, thou borest thy ass on thy back o'er
the dirt: thou hadst little wit in thy bald crown,
when thou gavest thy golden one away. If I speak
like myself in this, let him be whipped that first
finds it so.
Fools had ne'er less wit in a year;
For wise men are grown foppish,
They know not how their wits to wear,
Their manners are so apish.
enriched.character_situation: The Fool criticizes Lear's foolish decision to divide his kingdom through an extended metaphor about splitting an egg. He laments how wise men have become foolish while fools speak truth.

enriched.quote: I have used it, nuncle, ever since thou madest thy / daughters thy mothers: for when thou gavest them / the rod, and put'st down thine own breeches, / Then they for sudden joy did weep,
enriched.full_text:
I have used it, nuncle, ever since thou madest thy
daughters thy mothers: for when thou gavest them
the rod, and put'st down thine own breeches,
Then they for sudden joy did weep,
And I for sorrow sung,
That such a king should play bo-peep,
And go the fools among.
Prithee, nuncle, keep a schoolmaster that can teach
thy fool to lie: I would fain learn to lie.
enriched.character_situation: The Fool reflects on how the natural order has been inverted since Lear gave his power to his daughters. He feels trapped between truth-telling and survival, wishing he could learn to lie.

enriched.quote: I marvel what kin thou and thy daughters are: / they'll have me whipped for speaking true, thou'lt / have me whipped for lying; and sometimes I am / whipped for holding my peace. I had rather be any
enriched.full_text:
I marvel what kin thou and thy daughters are:
they'll have me whipped for speaking true, thou'lt
have me whipped for lying; and sometimes I am
whipped for holding my peace. I had rather be any
kind o' thing than a fool: and yet I would not be
thee, nuncle; thou hast pared thy wit o' both sides,
and left nothing i' the middle: here comes one o'
the parings.
enriched.character_situation: The Fool expresses his impossible position of being punished whether he speaks truth, lies, or remains silent. He observes Lear's complete loss of wisdom and power.

enriched.quote: Thou wast a pretty fellow when thou hadst no need to / care for her frowning; now thou art an O without a / figure: I am better than thou art now; I am a fool, / thou art nothing.
enriched.full_text:
Thou wast a pretty fellow when thou hadst no need to
care for her frowning; now thou art an O without a
figure: I am better than thou art now; I am a fool,
thou art nothing.
Yes, forsooth, I will hold my tongue; so your face
bids me, though you say nothing. Mum, mum,
He that keeps nor crust nor crum,
Weary of all, shall want some.
That's a shealed peascod.
enriched.character_situation: The Fool brutally tells Lear that he has become 'nothing' after giving away his power and identity. He warns of the consequences of having nothing left to give.

enriched.quote: Not only, sir, this your all-licensed fool, / But other of your insolent retinue / Do hourly carp and quarrel; breaking forth / In rank and not-to-be endured riots. Sir,
enriched.full_text:
Not only, sir, this your all-licensed fool,
But other of your insolent retinue
Do hourly carp and quarrel; breaking forth
In rank and not-to-be endured riots. Sir,
I had thought, by making this well known unto you,
To have found a safe redress; but now grow fearful,
By what yourself too late have spoke and done.
That you protect this course, and put it on
By your allowance; which if you should, the fault
Would not 'scape censure, nor the redresses sleep,
Which, in the tender of a wholesome weal,
Might in their working do you that offence,
Which else were shame, that then necessity
Will call discreet proceeding.
enriched.character_situation: Goneril confronts her father about his retinue's disruptive behavior in her household. She diplomatically but firmly demands he reduce his followers or face consequences.

enriched.quote: This admiration, sir, is much o' the savour / Of other your new pranks. I do beseech you / To understand my purposes aright: / As you are old and reverend, you should be wise.
enriched.full_text:
This admiration, sir, is much o' the savour
Of other your new pranks. I do beseech you
To understand my purposes aright:
As you are old and reverend, you should be wise.
Here do you keep a hundred knights and squires;
Men so disorder'd, so debosh'd and bold,
That this our court, infected with their manners,
Shows like a riotous inn: epicurism and lust
Make it more like a tavern or a brothel
Than a graced palace. The shame itself doth speak
For instant remedy: be then desired
By her, that else will take the thing she begs,
A little to disquantity your train;
And the remainder, that shall still depend,
To be such men as may besort your age,
And know themselves and you.
enriched.character_situation: Goneril more directly criticizes Lear's household as chaotic and inappropriate for her palace. She demands he reduce his train and choose more suitable companions for his age.

enriched.quote: [To GONERIL]  Detested kite! thou liest. / My train are men of choice and rarest parts, / That all particulars of duty know, / And in the most exact regard support
enriched.full_text:
[To GONERIL]  Detested kite! thou liest.
My train are men of choice and rarest parts,
That all particulars of duty know,
And in the most exact regard support
The worships of their name. O most small fault,
How ugly didst thou in Cordelia show!
That, like an engine, wrench'd my frame of nature
From the fix'd place; drew from heart all love,
And added to the gall. O Lear, Lear, Lear!
Beat at this gate, that let thy folly in,
And thy dear judgment out! Go, go, my people.
enriched.character_situation: Lear explodes in rage at Goneril's criticism, defending his followers while simultaneously recognizing his error in banishing Cordelia. He begins to see his own folly too late.

enriched.quote: It may be so, my lord. / Hear, nature, hear; dear goddess, hear! / Suspend thy purpose, if thou didst intend / To make this creature fruitful!
enriched.full_text:
It may be so, my lord.
Hear, nature, hear; dear goddess, hear!
Suspend thy purpose, if thou didst intend
To make this creature fruitful!
Into her womb convey sterility!
Dry up in her the organs of increase;
And from her derogate body never spring
A babe to honour her! If she must teem,
Create her child of spleen; that it may live,
And be a thwart disnatured torment to her!
Let it stamp wrinkles in her brow of youth;
With cadent tears fret channels in her cheeks;
Turn all her mother's pains and benefits
To laughter and contempt; that she may feel
How sharper than a serpent's tooth it is
To have a thankless child! Away, away!
enriched.character_situation: Lear calls upon Nature to curse Goneril with sterility or an ungrateful child, wanting her to experience the pain of filial ingratitude that he feels she has inflicted upon him.

enriched.quote: I'll tell thee: / Life and death! I am ashamed / That thou hast power to shake my manhood thus; / That these hot tears, which break from me perforce,
enriched.full_text:
I'll tell thee:
Life and death! I am ashamed
That thou hast power to shake my manhood thus;
That these hot tears, which break from me perforce,
Should make thee worth them. Blasts and fogs upon thee!
The untented woundings of a father's curse
Pierce every sense about thee! Old fond eyes,
Beweep this cause again, I'll pluck ye out,
And cast you, with the waters that you lose,
To temper clay. Yea, it is come to this?
Let is be so: yet have I left a daughter,
Who, I am sure, is kind and comfortable:
When she shall hear this of thee, with her nails
She'll flay thy wolvish visage. Thou shalt find
That I'll resume the shape which thou dost think
I have cast off for ever: thou shalt,
I warrant thee.
enriched.character_situation: Lear struggles with his overwhelming emotions and tears, feeling ashamed of his vulnerability while cursing Goneril. He desperately hopes his other daughter Regan will treat him better.

enriched.quote: Safer than trust too far: / Let me still take away the harms I fear, / Not fear still to be taken: I know his heart. / What he hath utter'd I have writ my sister
enriched.full_text:
Safer than trust too far:
Let me still take away the harms I fear,
Not fear still to be taken: I know his heart.
What he hath utter'd I have writ my sister
If she sustain him and his hundred knights
When I have show'd the unfitness,--
How now, Oswald!
What, have you writ that letter to my sister?
enriched.character_situation: Goneril is plotting to turn her sister Regan against their father King Lear by writing about his unfitness and the burden of his hundred knights. She is taking preemptive action against what she perceives as threats from her father.

enriched.quote: Take you some company, and away to horse: / Inform her full of my particular fear; / And thereto add such reasons of your own / As may compact it more. Get you gone;
enriched.full_text:
Take you some company, and away to horse:
Inform her full of my particular fear;
And thereto add such reasons of your own
As may compact it more. Get you gone;
And hasten your return.
No, no, my lord,
This milky gentleness and course of yours
Though I condemn not, yet, under pardon,
You are much more attask'd for want of wisdom
Than praised for harmful mildness.
enriched.character_situation: Goneril is instructing a messenger to carry her fears about Lear to Regan while also criticizing her husband Albany for being too gentle and mild in his approach to dealing with the situation. She seeks to consolidate power through manipulation.

enriched.quote: The duke be here to-night? The better! best! / This weaves itself perforce into my business. / My father hath set guard to take my brother; / And I have one thing, of a queasy question,
enriched.full_text:
The duke be here to-night? The better! best!
This weaves itself perforce into my business.
My father hath set guard to take my brother;
And I have one thing, of a queasy question,
Which I must act: briefness and fortune, work!
Brother, a word; descend: brother, I say!
My father watches: O sir, fly this place;
Intelligence is given where you are hid;
You have now the good advantage of the night:
Have you not spoken 'gainst the Duke of Cornwall?
He's coming hither: now, i' the night, i' the haste,
And Regan with him: have you nothing said
Upon his party 'gainst the Duke of Albany?
Advise yourself.
enriched.character_situation: Edmund is seizing an opportune moment when Cornwall arrives to further his scheme against his brother Edgar. He is orchestrating Edgar's downfall by warning him of supposed danger while actually setting a trap.

enriched.quote: I hear my father coming: pardon me: / In cunning I must draw my sword upon you / Draw; seem to defend yourself; now quit you well. / Yield: come before my father. Light, ho, here!
enriched.full_text:
I hear my father coming: pardon me:
In cunning I must draw my sword upon you
Draw; seem to defend yourself; now quit you well.
Yield: come before my father. Light, ho, here!
Fly, brother. Torches, torches! So, farewell.
Some blood drawn on me would beget opinion.
Of my more fierce endeavour: I have seen drunkards
Do more than this in sport. Father, father!
Stop, stop! No help?
enriched.character_situation: Edmund is executing his deception by staging a fake fight with Edgar and wounding himself to make his story convincing to their father Gloucester. He is manipulating the situation to frame his innocent brother.

enriched.quote: Persuade me to the murder of your lordship; / But that I told him, the revenging gods / 'Gainst parricides did all their thunders bend; / Spoke, with how manifold and strong a bond
enriched.full_text:
Persuade me to the murder of your lordship;
But that I told him, the revenging gods
'Gainst parricides did all their thunders bend;
Spoke, with how manifold and strong a bond
