The child was bound to the father; sir, in fine,
Seeing how loathly opposite I stood
To his unnatural purpose, in fell motion,
With his prepared sword, he charges home
My unprovided body, lanced mine arm:
But when he saw my best alarum'd spirits,
Bold in the quarrel's right, roused to the encounter,
Or whether gasted by the noise I made,
Full suddenly he fled.
enriched.character_situation: Edmund is lying to Gloucester about Edgar's supposed attempt to murder him, fabricating a story about how he nobly defended their father and fought off Edgar's attack. He is deepening his deception to secure Edgar's banishment.

enriched.quote: Let him fly far: / Not in this land shall he remain uncaught; / And found--dispatch. The noble duke my master, / My worthy arch and patron, comes to-night:
enriched.full_text:
Let him fly far:
Not in this land shall he remain uncaught;
And found--dispatch. The noble duke my master,
My worthy arch and patron, comes to-night:
By his authority I will proclaim it,
That he which finds him shall deserve our thanks,
Bringing the murderous coward to the stake;
He that conceals him, death.
enriched.character_situation: Gloucester has been completely deceived by Edmund and now seeks to hunt down his innocent son Edgar as a murderous traitor. He is proclaiming Edgar an outlaw and promising rewards for his capture.

enriched.quote: When I dissuaded him from his intent, / And found him pight to do it, with curst speech / I threaten'd to discover him: he replied, / 'Thou unpossessing bastard! dost thou think,
enriched.full_text:
When I dissuaded him from his intent,
And found him pight to do it, with curst speech
I threaten'd to discover him: he replied,
'Thou unpossessing bastard! dost thou think,
If I would stand against thee, would the reposal
Of any trust, virtue, or worth in thee
Make thy words faith'd? No: what I should deny,--
As this I would: ay, though thou didst produce
My very character,--I'ld turn it all
To thy suggestion, plot, and damned practise:
And thou must make a dullard of the world,
If they not thought the profits of my death
Were very pregnant and potential spurs
To make thee seek it.'
enriched.character_situation: Edmund continues his elaborate lies, claiming that Edgar called him a bastard and said no one would believe Edmund's word against Edgar's legitimate status. He is manipulating Gloucester's emotions and prejudices to solidify Edgar's exile.

enriched.quote: Strong and fasten'd villain / Would he deny his letter? I never got him. / Hark, the duke's trumpets! I know not why he comes. / All ports I'll bar; the villain shall not 'scape;
enriched.full_text:
Strong and fasten'd villain
Would he deny his letter? I never got him.
Hark, the duke's trumpets! I know not why he comes.
All ports I'll bar; the villain shall not 'scape;
The duke must grant me that: besides, his picture
I will send far and near, that all the kingdom
May have the due note of him; and of my land,
Loyal and natural boy, I'll work the means
To make thee capable.
enriched.character_situation: Gloucester is completely convinced of Edgar's guilt and vows to hunt him down across the kingdom while praising Edmund as his loyal and natural son. He promises to make Edmund his heir.

enriched.quote: If he be taken, he shall never more / Be fear'd of doing harm: make your own purpose, / How in my strength you please. For you, Edmund, / Whose virtue and obedience doth this instant
enriched.full_text:
If he be taken, he shall never more
Be fear'd of doing harm: make your own purpose,
How in my strength you please. For you, Edmund,
Whose virtue and obedience doth this instant
So much commend itself, you shall be ours:
Natures of such deep trust we shall much need;
You we first seize on.
enriched.character_situation: Cornwall is rewarding Edmund for his supposed loyalty and virtue by taking him into his service and granting him authority. He sees Edmund as trustworthy and valuable to his cause.

enriched.quote: Thus out of season, threading dark-eyed night: / Occasions, noble Gloucester, of some poise, / Wherein we must have use of your advice: / Our father he hath writ, so hath our sister,
enriched.full_text:
Thus out of season, threading dark-eyed night:
Occasions, noble Gloucester, of some poise,
Wherein we must have use of your advice:
Our father he hath writ, so hath our sister,
Of differences, which I least thought it fit
To answer from our home; the several messengers
From hence attend dispatch. Our good old friend,
Lay comforts to your bosom; and bestow
Your needful counsel to our business,
Which craves the instant use.
enriched.character_situation: Regan has traveled through the night to seek Gloucester's counsel about the conflict with her father Lear and sister Goneril. She needs his advice and support in navigating the family crisis and political situation.

enriched.quote: A knave; a rascal; an eater of broken meats; a / base, proud, shallow, beggarly, three-suited, / hundred-pound, filthy, worsted-stocking knave; a / lily-livered, action-taking knave, a whoreson,
enriched.full_text:
A knave; a rascal; an eater of broken meats; a
base, proud, shallow, beggarly, three-suited,
hundred-pound, filthy, worsted-stocking knave; a
lily-livered, action-taking knave, a whoreson,
glass-gazing, super-serviceable finical rogue;
one-trunk-inheriting slave; one that wouldst be a
bawd, in way of good service, and art nothing but
the composition of a knave, beggar, coward, pandar,
and the son and heir of a mongrel bitch: one whom I
will beat into clamorous whining, if thou deniest
the least syllable of thy addition.
enriched.character_situation: Kent is unleashing a torrent of insults at Oswald, expressing his contempt for servile, dishonest courtiers. He is defending honor and plain-dealing against what he sees as corrupt flattery.

enriched.quote: What a brazen-faced varlet art thou, to deny thou / knowest me! Is it two days ago since I tripped up / thy heels, and beat thee before the king? Draw, you / rogue: for, though it be night, yet the moon
enriched.full_text:
What a brazen-faced varlet art thou, to deny thou
knowest me! Is it two days ago since I tripped up
thy heels, and beat thee before the king? Draw, you
rogue: for, though it be night, yet the moon
shines; I'll make a sop o' the moonshine of you:
draw, you whoreson cullionly barber-monger, draw.
enriched.character_situation: Kent confronts Oswald again, incredulous at his denial of their previous encounter. He is ready to fight, driven by righteous indignation at the steward's dishonesty.

enriched.quote: That such a slave as this should wear a sword, / Who wears no honesty. Such smiling rogues as these, / Like rats, oft bite the holy cords a-twain / Which are too intrinse t' unloose; smooth every passion
enriched.full_text:
That such a slave as this should wear a sword,
Who wears no honesty. Such smiling rogues as these,
Like rats, oft bite the holy cords a-twain
Which are too intrinse t' unloose; smooth every passion
That in the natures of their lords rebel;
Bring oil to fire, snow to their colder moods;
Renege, affirm, and turn their halcyon beaks
With every gale and vary of their masters,
Knowing nought, like dogs, but following.
A plague upon your epileptic visage!
Smile you my speeches, as I were a fool?
Goose, if I had you upon Sarum plain,
I'ld drive ye cackling home to Camelot.
enriched.character_situation: Kent delivers a philosophical condemnation of servile courtiers who manipulate their masters through flattery. He is expressing his disgust at the corruption of natural bonds and honest service.

enriched.quote: Sir, 'tis my occupation to be plain: / I have seen better faces in my time / Than stands on any shoulder that I see / Before me at this instant.
enriched.full_text:
Sir, 'tis my occupation to be plain:
I have seen better faces in my time
Than stands on any shoulder that I see
Before me at this instant.
enriched.character_situation: Kent explains his blunt nature as a professional duty, asserting that he values honesty over flattery. He is defending his direct manner of speaking.

enriched.quote: This is some fellow, / Who, having been praised for bluntness, doth affect / A saucy roughness, and constrains the garb / Quite from his nature: he cannot flatter, he,
enriched.full_text:
This is some fellow,
Who, having been praised for bluntness, doth affect
A saucy roughness, and constrains the garb
Quite from his nature: he cannot flatter, he,
An honest mind and plain, he must speak truth!
An they will take it, so; if not, he's plain.
These kind of knaves I know, which in this plainness
Harbour more craft and more corrupter ends
Than twenty silly ducking observants
That stretch their duties nicely.
enriched.character_situation: Cornwall analyzes Kent's behavior, arguing that his bluntness is itself an affectation that masks craftiness. He is suspicious of those who claim to be plain speakers.

enriched.quote: I never gave him any: / It pleased the king his master very late / To strike at me, upon his misconstruction; / When he, conjunct and flattering his displeasure,
enriched.full_text:
I never gave him any:
It pleased the king his master very late
To strike at me, upon his misconstruction;
When he, conjunct and flattering his displeasure,
Tripp'd me behind; being down, insulted, rail'd,
And put upon him such a deal of man,
That worthied him, got praises of the king
For him attempting who was self-subdued;
And, in the fleshment of this dread exploit,
Drew on me here again.
enriched.character_situation: Oswald defends himself by explaining how Kent attacked him previously without provocation. He portrays himself as an innocent victim of Kent's aggression.

enriched.quote: Let me beseech your grace not to do so: / His fault is much, and the good king his master / Will cheque him for 't: your purposed low correction / Is such as basest and contemned'st wretches
enriched.full_text:
Let me beseech your grace not to do so:
His fault is much, and the good king his master
Will cheque him for 't: your purposed low correction
Is such as basest and contemned'st wretches
For pilferings and most common trespasses
Are punish'd with: the king must take it ill,
That he's so slightly valued in his messenger,
Should have him thus restrain'd.
enriched.character_situation: Gloucester attempts to mediate, warning Cornwall that punishing Kent in the stocks will be seen as an insult to King Lear. He is trying to prevent a political disaster.

enriched.quote: Good king, that must approve the common saw, / Thou out of heaven's benediction comest / To the warm sun! / Approach, thou beacon to this under globe,
enriched.full_text:
Good king, that must approve the common saw,
Thou out of heaven's benediction comest
To the warm sun!
Approach, thou beacon to this under globe,
That by thy comfortable beams I may
Peruse this letter! Nothing almost sees miracles
But misery: I know 'tis from Cordelia,
Who hath most fortunately been inform'd
Of my obscured course; and shall find time
From this enormous state, seeking to give
Losses their remedies. All weary and o'erwatch'd,
Take vantage, heavy eyes, not to behold
This shameful lodging.
Fortune, good night: smile once more: turn thy wheel!
enriched.character_situation: Kent, imprisoned in the stocks, reflects on his fall from grace while finding hope in a letter from Cordelia. He endures his punishment with stoic resignation while maintaining faith in eventual justice.

enriched.quote: I heard myself proclaim'd; / And by the happy hollow of a tree / Escaped the hunt. No port is free; no place, / That guard, and most unusual vigilance,
enriched.full_text:
I heard myself proclaim'd;
And by the happy hollow of a tree
Escaped the hunt. No port is free; no place,
That guard, and most unusual vigilance,
Does not attend my taking. Whiles I may 'scape,
I will preserve myself: and am bethought
To take the basest and most poorest shape
That ever penury, in contempt of man,
Brought near to beast: my face I'll grime with filth;
Blanket my loins: elf all my hair in knots;
And with presented nakedness out-face
The winds and persecutions of the sky.
The country gives me proof and precedent
Of Bedlam beggars, who, with roaring voices,
Strike in their numb'd and mortified bare arms
Pins, wooden pricks, nails, sprigs of rosemary;
And with this horrible object, from low farms,
Poor pelting villages, sheep-cotes, and mills,
Sometime with lunatic bans, sometime with prayers,
Enforce their charity. Poor Turlygod! poor Tom!
That's something yet: Edgar I nothing am.
enriched.character_situation: Edgar, fleeing as a wanted man, decides to transform himself into 'Poor Tom,' a mad beggar, to survive. He is embracing a complete loss of identity to preserve his life.

enriched.quote: My lord, when at their home / I did commend your highness' letters to them, / Ere I was risen from the place that show'd / My duty kneeling, came there a reeking post,
enriched.full_text:
My lord, when at their home
I did commend your highness' letters to them,
Ere I was risen from the place that show'd
My duty kneeling, came there a reeking post,
Stew'd in his haste, half breathless, panting forth
From Goneril his mistress salutations;
Deliver'd letters, spite of intermission,
Which presently they read: on whose contents,
They summon'd up their meiny, straight took horse;
Commanded me to follow, and attend
The leisure of their answer; gave me cold looks:
And meeting here the other messenger,
Whose welcome, I perceived, had poison'd mine,--
Being the very fellow that of late
Display'd so saucily against your highness,--
Having more man than wit about me, drew:
He raised the house with loud and coward cries.
Your son and daughter found this trespass worth
The shame which here it suffers.
enriched.character_situation: Kent explains to Lear how he came to be in the stocks, describing his mission to Regan and Cornwall and his confrontation with Oswald. He is reporting his loyal service despite his humiliation.

enriched.quote: Winter's not gone yet, if the wild-geese fly that way. / Fathers that wear rags / Do make their children blind; / But fathers that bear bags
enriched.full_text:
Winter's not gone yet, if the wild-geese fly that way.
Fathers that wear rags
Do make their children blind;
But fathers that bear bags
Shall see their children kind.
Fortune, that arrant whore,
Ne'er turns the key to the poor.
But, for all this, thou shalt have as many dolours
for thy daughters as thou canst tell in a year.
enriched.character_situation: The Fool observes Lear's deteriorating situation and warns him about the harsh consequences of his poor judgment. He uses bitter wisdom and metaphors to point out how fortune abandons the poor and powerless.

enriched.quote: We'll set thee to school to an ant, to teach thee / there's no labouring i' the winter. All that follow / their noses are led by their eyes but blind men; and / there's not a nose among twenty but can smell him
enriched.full_text:
We'll set thee to school to an ant, to teach thee
there's no labouring i' the winter. All that follow
their noses are led by their eyes but blind men; and
there's not a nose among twenty but can smell him
that's stinking. Let go thy hold when a great wheel
runs down a hill, lest it break thy neck with
following it: but the great one that goes up the
hill, let him draw thee after. When a wise man
gives thee better counsel, give me mine again: I
would have none but knaves follow it, since a fool gives it.
That sir which serves and seeks for gain,
And follows but for form,
Will pack when it begins to rain,
And leave thee in the storm,
But I will tarry; the fool will stay,
And let the wise man fly:
The knave turns fool that runs away;
The fool no knave, perdy.
enriched.character_situation: The Fool delivers practical wisdom about loyalty and survival, teaching Lear about the nature of fair-weather friends while declaring his own steadfast devotion. He contrasts wise self-preservation with foolish loyalty.

enriched.quote: The king would speak with Cornwall; the dear father / Would with his daughter speak, commands her service: / Are they inform'd of this? My breath and blood! / Fiery? the fiery duke? Tell the hot duke that--
enriched.full_text:
The king would speak with Cornwall; the dear father
Would with his daughter speak, commands her service:
Are they inform'd of this? My breath and blood!
Fiery? the fiery duke? Tell the hot duke that--
No, but not yet: may be he is not well:
Infirmity doth still neglect all office
Whereto our health is bound; we are not ourselves
When nature, being oppress'd, commands the mind
To suffer with the body: I'll forbear;
And am fall'n out with my more headier will,
To take the indisposed and sickly fit
For the sound man. Death on my state! wherefore
Should he sit here? This act persuades me
That this remotion of the duke and her
Is practise only. Give me my servant forth.
Go tell the duke and 's wife I'ld speak with them,
Now, presently: bid them come forth and hear me,
Or at their chamber-door I'll beat the drum
Till it cry sleep to death.
enriched.character_situation: Lear struggles with his diminished authority as he tries to rationalize Cornwall's disrespectful behavior while his anger builds. He attempts to maintain royal dignity despite being increasingly powerless.

enriched.quote: Regan, I think you are; I know what reason / I have to think so: if thou shouldst not be glad, / I would divorce me from thy mother's tomb, / Sepulchring an adultress.
enriched.full_text:
Regan, I think you are; I know what reason
I have to think so: if thou shouldst not be glad,
I would divorce me from thy mother's tomb,
Sepulchring an adultress.
O, are you free?
Some other time for that. Beloved Regan,
Thy sister's naught: O Regan, she hath tied
Sharp-tooth'd unkindness, like a vulture, here:
I can scarce speak to thee; thou'lt not believe
With how depraved a quality--O Regan!
enriched.character_situation: Lear seeks comfort from Regan after Goneril's rejection, expressing his pain and hoping to find a loving daughter who will treat him with kindness. He is emotionally wounded and vulnerable.

enriched.quote: O, sir, you are old. / Nature in you stands on the very verge / Of her confine: you should be ruled and led / By some discretion, that discerns your state
enriched.full_text:
O, sir, you are old.
Nature in you stands on the very verge
Of her confine: you should be ruled and led
By some discretion, that discerns your state
Better than you yourself. Therefore, I pray you,
That to our sister you do make return;
Say you have wrong'd her, sir.
enriched.character_situation: Regan coldly manipulates her father by using his age against him, suggesting he lacks judgment and should submit to his daughters' authority. She shows calculated cruelty disguised as reasonable advice.

enriched.quote: No, Regan, thou shalt never have my curse: / Thy tender-hefted nature shall not give / Thee o'er to harshness: her eyes are fierce; but thine / Do comfort and not burn. 'Tis not in thee
enriched.full_text:
No, Regan, thou shalt never have my curse:
Thy tender-hefted nature shall not give
Thee o'er to harshness: her eyes are fierce; but thine
Do comfort and not burn. 'Tis not in thee
To grudge my pleasures, to cut off my train,
To bandy hasty words, to scant my sizes,
And in conclusion to oppose the bolt
Against my coming in: thou better know'st
The offices of nature, bond of childhood,
Effects of courtesy, dues of gratitude;
Thy half o' the kingdom hast thou not forgot,
Wherein I thee endow'd.
enriched.character_situation: Lear desperately tries to believe Regan is different from Goneril, clinging to the hope that she will honor their family bond. He reminds her of his generosity and expects filial gratitude.

enriched.quote: Return to her, and fifty men dismiss'd? / No, rather I abjure all roofs, and choose / To wage against the enmity o' the air; / To be a comrade with the wolf and owl,--
enriched.full_text:
Return to her, and fifty men dismiss'd?
No, rather I abjure all roofs, and choose
To wage against the enmity o' the air;
To be a comrade with the wolf and owl,--
Necessity's sharp pinch! Return with her?
Why, the hot-blooded France, that dowerless took
Our youngest born, I could as well be brought
To knee his throne, and, squire-like; pension beg
To keep base life afoot. Return with her?
Persuade me rather to be slave and sumpter
To this detested groom.
enriched.character_situation: Lear faces the humiliating prospect of returning to Goneril and chooses defiant exile over submission. He would rather face the wilderness than compromise his remaining dignity.

enriched.quote: I prithee, daughter, do not make me mad: / I will not trouble thee, my child; farewell: / We'll no more meet, no more see one another: / But yet thou art my flesh, my blood, my daughter;
enriched.full_text:
I prithee, daughter, do not make me mad:
I will not trouble thee, my child; farewell:
We'll no more meet, no more see one another:
But yet thou art my flesh, my blood, my daughter;
Or rather a disease that's in my flesh,
Which I must needs call mine: thou art a boil,
A plague-sore, an embossed carbuncle,
In my corrupted blood. But I'll not chide thee;
Let shame come when it will, I do not call it:
I do not bid the thunder-bearer shoot,
Nor tell tales of thee to high-judging Jove:
Mend when thou canst; be better at thy leisure:
I can be patient; I can stay with Regan,
I and my hundred knights.
enriched.character_situation: Lear desperately pleads with Goneril while his rage builds, comparing her to a disease in his flesh. He struggles between paternal love and fury at her ingratitude.

enriched.quote: I dare avouch it, sir: what, fifty followers? / Is it not well? What should you need of more? / Yea, or so many, sith that both charge and danger / Speak 'gainst so great a number? How, in one house,
enriched.full_text:
I dare avouch it, sir: what, fifty followers?
Is it not well? What should you need of more?
Yea, or so many, sith that both charge and danger
Speak 'gainst so great a number? How, in one house,
Should many people, under two commands,
Hold amity? 'Tis hard; almost impossible.
enriched.character_situation: Regan continues to strip away Lear's retinue and dignity, using practical arguments to justify reducing his followers. She shows calculated manipulation disguised as reasonable household management.

enriched.quote: Why not, my lord? If then they chanced to slack you, / We could control them. If you will come to me,-- / For now I spy a danger,--I entreat you / To bring but five and twenty: to no more
enriched.full_text:
Why not, my lord? If then they chanced to slack you,
We could control them. If you will come to me,--
For now I spy a danger,--I entreat you
To bring but five and twenty: to no more
Will I give place or notice.
enriched.character_situation: Regan further reduces Lear's retinue to a mere twenty-five followers, tightening her control while presenting it as a generous compromise. She systematically dismantles his remaining power and dignity.

enriched.quote: O, reason not the need: our basest beggars / Are in the poorest thing superfluous: / Allow not nature more than nature needs, / Man's life's as cheap as beast's: thou art a lady;
enriched.full_text:
O, reason not the need: our basest beggars
Are in the poorest thing superfluous:
Allow not nature more than nature needs,
Man's life's as cheap as beast's: thou art a lady;
If only to go warm were gorgeous,
Why, nature needs not what thou gorgeous wear'st,
Which scarcely keeps thee warm. But, for true need,--
You heavens, give me that patience, patience I need!
You see me here, you gods, a poor old man,
As full of grief as age; wretched in both!
If it be you that stir these daughters' hearts
Against their father, fool me not so much
To bear it tamely; touch me with noble anger,
And let not women's weapons, water-drops,
Stain my man's cheeks! No, you unnatural hags,
I will have such revenges on you both,
That all the world shall--I will do such things,--
What they are, yet I know not: but they shall be
The terrors of the earth. You think I'll weep
No, I'll not weep:
I have full cause of weeping; but this heart
Shall break into a hundred thousand flaws,
Or ere I'll weep. O fool, I shall go mad!
enriched.character_situation: Lear rages against his daughters who deny him basic dignity and needs, feeling stripped of all authority and respect. He teeters on the edge of madness as he confronts his complete powerlessness.

enriched.quote: O, sir, to wilful men, / The injuries that they themselves procure / Must be their schoolmasters. Shut up your doors: / He is attended with a desperate train;
enriched.full_text:
O, sir, to wilful men,
The injuries that they themselves procure
Must be their schoolmasters. Shut up your doors:
He is attended with a desperate train;
And what they may incense him to, being apt
To have his ear abused, wisdom bids fear.
enriched.character_situation: Regan coldly justifies shutting out her father, claiming his suffering is self-inflicted and he poses a danger. She shows no compassion for Lear's plight.

enriched.quote: Contending with the fretful element: / Bids the winds blow the earth into the sea, / Or swell the curled water 'bove the main, / That things might change or cease; tears his white hair,
enriched.full_text:
Contending with the fretful element:
Bids the winds blow the earth into the sea,
Or swell the curled water 'bove the main,
That things might change or cease; tears his white hair,
Which the impetuous blasts, with eyeless rage,
Catch in their fury, and make nothing of;
Strives in his little world of man to out-scorn
The to-and-fro-conflicting wind and rain.
This night, wherein the cub-drawn bear would couch,
The lion and the belly-pinched wolf
Keep their fur dry, unbonneted he runs,
And bids what will take all.
enriched.character_situation: The Gentleman describes Lear's desperate battle against the storm, portraying a king reduced to raging helplessly against nature itself. He witnesses Lear's complete abandonment of all hope and dignity.

enriched.quote: Sir, I do know you; / And dare, upon the warrant of my note, / Commend a dear thing to you. There is division, / Although as yet the face of it be cover'd
enriched.full_text:
Sir, I do know you;
And dare, upon the warrant of my note,
Commend a dear thing to you. There is division,
Although as yet the face of it be cover'd
With mutual cunning, 'twixt Albany and Cornwall;
Who have--as who have not, that their great stars
Throned and set high?--servants, who seem no less,
Which are to France the spies and speculations
Intelligent of our state; what hath been seen,
Either in snuffs and packings of the dukes,
Or the hard rein which both of them have borne
Against the old kind king; or something deeper,
Whereof perchance these are but furnishings;
But, true it is, from France there comes a power
Into this scatter'd kingdom; who already,
Wise in our negligence, have secret feet
In some of our best ports, and are at point
To show their open banner. Now to you:
If on my credit you dare build so far
To make your speed to Dover, you shall find
Some that will thank you, making just report
Of how unnatural and bemadding sorrow
The king hath cause to plain.
I am a gentleman of blood and breeding;
And, from some knowledge and assurance, offer
This office to you.
enriched.character_situation: Kent reveals political intelligence about brewing conflict and foreign invasion while maintaining his loyal service to Lear. He works secretly to restore order and protect his master.

enriched.quote: No, do not. / For confirmation that I am much more / Than my out-wall, open this purse, and take / What it contains. If you shall see Cordelia,--
enriched.full_text:
No, do not.
For confirmation that I am much more
Than my out-wall, open this purse, and take
What it contains. If you shall see Cordelia,--
As fear not but you shall,--show her this ring;
And she will tell you who your fellow is
That yet you do not know. Fie on this storm!
I will go seek the king.
enriched.character_situation: Kent continues his faithful service despite the storm, giving what aid he can while maintaining his disguised identity. He shows unwavering loyalty even in the face of natural and political chaos.

enriched.quote: Blow, winds, and crack your cheeks! rage! blow! / You cataracts and hurricanoes, spout / Till you have drench'd our steeples, drown'd the cocks! / You sulphurous and thought-executing fires,
enriched.full_text:
Blow, winds, and crack your cheeks! rage! blow!
You cataracts and hurricanoes, spout
Till you have drench'd our steeples, drown'd the cocks!
You sulphurous and thought-executing fires,
Vaunt-couriers to oak-cleaving thunderbolts,
Singe my white head! And thou, all-shaking thunder,
Smite flat the thick rotundity o' the world!
Crack nature's moulds, an germens spill at once,
That make ingrateful man!
enriched.character_situation: Lear calls upon the storm to destroy the world and all of humanity, expressing his complete disillusionment with mankind. He embraces destruction as preferable to the cruelty he has experienced.

enriched.quote: Rumble thy bellyful! Spit, fire! spout, rain! / Nor rain, wind, thunder, fire, are my daughters: / I tax not you, you elements, with unkindness; / I never gave you kingdom, call'd you children,
enriched.full_text:
Rumble thy bellyful! Spit, fire! spout, rain!
Nor rain, wind, thunder, fire, are my daughters:
I tax not you, you elements, with unkindness;
I never gave you kingdom, call'd you children,
You owe me no subscription: then let fall
Your horrible pleasure: here I stand, your slave,
A poor, infirm, weak, and despised old man:
But yet I call you servile ministers,
That have with two pernicious daughters join'd
Your high engender'd battles 'gainst a head
So old and white as this. O! O! 'tis foul!
enriched.character_situation: Lear distinguishes between the natural storm, which owes him nothing, and his daughters' unnatural cruelty toward their father. He acknowledges his vulnerability while condemning filial ingratitude.

enriched.quote: He that has a house to put's head in has a good / head-piece. / The cod-piece that will house / Before the head has any,
enriched.full_text:
He that has a house to put's head in has a good
head-piece.
The cod-piece that will house
Before the head has any,
The head and he shall louse;
So beggars marry many.
The man that makes his toe
What he his heart should make
Shall of a corn cry woe,
And turn his sleep to wake.
For there was never yet fair woman but she made
mouths in a glass.
enriched.character_situation: The Fool offers cryptic wisdom about the folly of prioritizing the wrong things, commenting on Lear's poor judgment. He uses riddles and jokes to convey harsh truths about human nature and vanity.

enriched.quote: Alas, sir, are you here? things that love night / Love not such nights as these; the wrathful skies / Gallow the very wanderers of the dark, / And make them keep their caves: since I was man,
enriched.full_text:
Alas, sir, are you here? things that love night
Love not such nights as these; the wrathful skies
Gallow the very wanderers of the dark,
And make them keep their caves: since I was man,
Such sheets of fire, such bursts of horrid thunder,
Such groans of roaring wind and rain, I never
Remember to have heard: man's nature cannot carry
The affliction nor the fear.
enriched.character_situation: Kent expresses horror at the unprecedented violence of the storm, recognizing it as beyond normal human endurance. He fears for both physical and psychological survival in such extreme conditions.

enriched.quote: Let the great gods, / That keep this dreadful pother o'er our heads, / Find out their enemies now. Tremble, thou wretch, / That hast within thee undivulged crimes,
enriched.full_text:
Let the great gods,
That keep this dreadful pother o'er our heads,
Find out their enemies now. Tremble, thou wretch,
That hast within thee undivulged crimes,
Unwhipp'd of justice: hide thee, thou bloody hand;
Thou perjured, and thou simular man of virtue
That art incestuous: caitiff, to pieces shake,
That under covert and convenient seeming
Hast practised on man's life: close pent-up guilts,
Rive your concealing continents, and cry
These dreadful summoners grace. I am a man
More sinn'd against than sinning.
enriched.character_situation: Lear calls upon the gods to use the storm as divine justice to expose hidden crimes and corruption. He claims moral superiority, asserting he has been more sinned against than sinning.

enriched.quote: Alack, bare-headed! / Gracious my lord, hard by here is a hovel; / Some friendship will it lend you 'gainst the tempest: / Repose you there; while I to this hard house--
enriched.full_text:
Alack, bare-headed!
Gracious my lord, hard by here is a hovel;
Some friendship will it lend you 'gainst the tempest:
Repose you there; while I to this hard house--
More harder than the stones whereof 'tis raised;
Which even but now, demanding after you,
Denied me to come in--return, and force
Their scanted courtesy.
enriched.character_situation: Kent shows deep concern for Lear's physical condition in the storm and faces cruel rejection from those who should provide shelter. He demonstrates unwavering loyalty despite being denied basic courtesy by Lear's own family.

enriched.quote: My wits begin to turn. / Come on, my boy: how dost, my boy? art cold? / I am cold myself. Where is this straw, my fellow? / The art of our necessities is strange,
enriched.full_text:
My wits begin to turn.
Come on, my boy: how dost, my boy? art cold?
I am cold myself. Where is this straw, my fellow?
The art of our necessities is strange,
That can make vile things precious. Come,
your hovel.
Poor fool and knave, I have one part in my heart
That's sorry yet for thee.
enriched.character_situation: Lear recognizes his mental state deteriorating while discovering empathy for others' suffering in his own moment of need. He begins to see beyond his royal self-absorption as adversity strips away his former identity.

enriched.quote: This is a brave night to cool a courtezan. / I'll speak a prophecy ere I go: / When priests are more in word than matter; / When brewers mar their malt with water;
enriched.character_situation: The Fool delivers a prophetic vision of social disorder while maintaining his role as truth-teller through dark humor. He uses the chaos of the storm to reflect on the corruption and absurdity of the world around them.

enriched.quote: Go to; say you nothing. There's a division betwixt / the dukes; and a worse matter than that: I have / received a letter this night; 'tis dangerous to be / spoken; I have locked the letter in my closet:
enriched.full_text:
Go to; say you nothing. There's a division betwixt
the dukes; and a worse matter than that: I have
received a letter this night; 'tis dangerous to be
spoken; I have locked the letter in my closet:
these injuries the king now bears will be revenged
home; there's part of a power already footed: we
must incline to the king. I will seek him, and
privily relieve him: go you and maintain talk with
the duke, that my charity be not of him perceived:
if he ask for me. I am ill, and gone to bed.
Though I die for it, as no less is threatened me,
the king my old master must be relieved. There is
some strange thing toward, Edmund; pray you, be careful.
enriched.character_situation: Gloucester faces a dangerous political situation and chooses loyalty to Lear despite threats to his life. He demonstrates courage while navigating treacherous family dynamics and political divisions.

enriched.quote: Thou think'st 'tis much that this contentious storm / Invades us to the skin: so 'tis to thee; / But where the greater malady is fix'd, / The lesser is scarce felt. Thou'ldst shun a bear;
enriched.full_text:
Thou think'st 'tis much that this contentious storm
Invades us to the skin: so 'tis to thee;
But where the greater malady is fix'd,
The lesser is scarce felt. Thou'ldst shun a bear;
But if thy flight lay toward the raging sea,
Thou'ldst meet the bear i' the mouth. When the
mind's free,
The body's delicate: the tempest in my mind
Doth from my senses take all feeling else
Save what beats there. Filial ingratitude!
Is it not as this mouth should tear this hand
For lifting food to't? But I will punish home:
No, I will weep no more. In such a night
To shut me out! Pour on; I will endure.
In such a night as this! O Regan, Goneril!
Your old kind father, whose frank heart gave all,--
O, that way madness lies; let me shun that;
No more of that.
enriched.character_situation: Lear compares the physical storm to his internal anguish over his daughters' betrayal and begins to understand the relationship between mental and physical pain. He struggles with rage, grief, and the onset of madness while trying to maintain some control.

enriched.quote: Prithee, go in thyself: seek thine own ease: / This tempest will not give me leave to ponder / On things would hurt me more. But I'll go in. / In, boy; go first. You houseless poverty,--
enriched.full_text:
Prithee, go in thyself: seek thine own ease:
This tempest will not give me leave to ponder
On things would hurt me more. But I'll go in.
In, boy; go first. You houseless poverty,--
Nay, get thee in. I'll pray, and then I'll sleep.
Poor naked wretches, whereso'er you are,
That bide the pelting of this pitiless storm,
How shall your houseless heads and unfed sides,
Your loop'd and window'd raggedness, defend you
From seasons such as these? O, I have ta'en
Too little care of this! Take physic, pomp;
Expose thyself to feel what wretches feel,
That thou mayst shake the superflux to them,
And show the heavens more just.
enriched.character_situation: Lear experiences a profound moral awakening as he recognizes his past failures toward the poor and powerless. His suffering opens his eyes to social injustice and his responsibility as a former ruler to care for his subjects.

enriched.quote: Who gives any thing to poor Tom? whom the foul / fiend hath led through fire and through flame, and / through ford and whirlipool e'er bog and quagmire; / that hath laid knives under his pillow, and halters
enriched.full_text:
Who gives any thing to poor Tom? whom the foul
fiend hath led through fire and through flame, and
through ford and whirlipool e'er bog and quagmire;
that hath laid knives under his pillow, and halters
in his pew; set ratsbane by his porridge; made film
proud of heart, to ride on a bay trotting-horse over
four-inched bridges, to course his own shadow for a
traitor. Bless thy five wits! Tom's a-cold,--O, do
de, do de, do de. Bless thee from whirlwinds,
star-blasting, and taking! Do poor Tom some
charity, whom the foul fiend vexes: there could I
have him now,--and there,--and there again, and there.
enriched.character_situation: Edgar maintains his disguise as Poor Tom, feigning madness to survive while actually being hunted as a fugitive. He performs the role of a tormented beggar while enduring real physical and emotional suffering.

enriched.quote: A serving-man, proud in heart and mind; that curled / my hair; wore gloves in my cap; served the lust of / my mistress' heart, and did the act of darkness with / her; swore as many oaths as I spake words, and
enriched.full_text:
A serving-man, proud in heart and mind; that curled
my hair; wore gloves in my cap; served the lust of
my mistress' heart, and did the act of darkness with
her; swore as many oaths as I spake words, and
broke them in the sweet face of heaven: one that
slept in the contriving of lust, and waked to do it:
wine loved I deeply, dice dearly: and in woman
out-paramoured the Turk: false of heart, light of
ear, bloody of hand; hog in sloth, fox in stealth,
wolf in greediness, dog in madness, lion in prey.
Let not the creaking of shoes nor the rustling of
silks betray thy poor heart to woman: keep thy foot
out of brothels, thy hand out of plackets, thy pen
from lenders' books, and defy the foul fiend.
Still through the hawthorn blows the cold wind:
Says suum, mun, ha, no, nonny.
Dolphin my boy, my boy, sessa! let him trot by.
enriched.character_situation: Edgar continues his Poor Tom performance by confessing to fictional sins and moral corruption while warning against vice. He uses his disguise to deliver moral lessons about the dangers of lust, pride, and deception.

enriched.quote: Why, thou wert better in thy grave than to answer / with thy uncovered body this extremity of the skies. / Is man no more than this? Consider him well. Thou / owest the worm no silk, the beast no hide, the sheep
enriched.full_text:
Why, thou wert better in thy grave than to answer
with thy uncovered body this extremity of the skies.
Is man no more than this? Consider him well. Thou
owest the worm no silk, the beast no hide, the sheep
no wool, the cat no perfume. Ha! here's three on
's are sophisticated! Thou art the thing itself:
unaccommodated man is no more but such a poor bare,
forked animal as thou art. Off, off, you lendings!
come unbutton here.
enriched.character_situation: Lear encounters Poor Tom and has a philosophical revelation about the nature of humanity stripped of social pretensions. He sees Tom's nakedness as representing essential human nature and begins to question all social constructs and material possessions.

enriched.quote: This is the foul fiend Flibbertigibbet: he begins / at curfew, and walks till the first cock; he gives / the web and the pin, squints the eye, and makes the / hare-lip; mildews the white wheat, and hurts the
enriched.full_text:
This is the foul fiend Flibbertigibbet: he begins
at curfew, and walks till the first cock; he gives
the web and the pin, squints the eye, and makes the
hare-lip; mildews the white wheat, and hurts the
poor creature of earth.
S. Withold footed thrice the old;
He met the night-mare, and her nine-fold;
Bid her alight,
And her troth plight,
And, aroint thee, witch, aroint thee!
enriched.character_situation: Edgar continues his Poor Tom act by invoking demonic possession and folk superstitions to maintain his disguise. He performs madness through references to evil spirits and traditional protective charms while enduring real hardship.

enriched.quote: Poor Tom; that eats the swimming frog, the toad, / the tadpole, the wall-newt and the water; that in / the fury of his heart, when the foul fiend rages, / eats cow-dung for sallets; swallows the old rat and
enriched.full_text:
Poor Tom; that eats the swimming frog, the toad,
the tadpole, the wall-newt and the water; that in
the fury of his heart, when the foul fiend rages,
eats cow-dung for sallets; swallows the old rat and
the ditch-dog; drinks the green mantle of the
standing pool; who is whipped from tithing to
tithing, and stock- punished, and imprisoned; who
hath had three suits to his back, six shirts to his
body, horse to ride, and weapon to wear;
But mice and rats, and such small deer,
Have been Tom's food for seven long year.
Beware my follower. Peace, Smulkin; peace, thou fiend!
enriched.character_situation: Edgar, disguised as Poor Tom the mad beggar, is performing his role to avoid detection while in exile. He describes the degraded existence of a mad vagrant to maintain his disguise and protect himself.

enriched.quote: Canst thou blame him? / His daughters seek his death: ah, that good Kent! / He said it would be thus, poor banish'd man! / Thou say'st the king grows mad; I'll tell thee, friend,
enriched.full_text:
Canst thou blame him?
His daughters seek his death: ah, that good Kent!
He said it would be thus, poor banish'd man!
Thou say'st the king grows mad; I'll tell thee, friend,
I am almost mad myself: I had a son,
Now outlaw'd from my blood; he sought my life,
But lately, very late: I loved him, friend;
No father his son dearer: truth to tell thee,
The grief hath crazed my wits. What a night's this!
I do beseech your grace,--
enriched.character_situation: Gloucester is overwhelmed by the chaos around him, believing his legitimate son Edgar has betrayed him while witnessing Lear's descent into madness. He feels his own sanity slipping as his world crumbles.

enriched.quote: [Aside]  If I find him comforting the king, it will / stuff his suspicion more fully.--I will persevere in / my course of loyalty, though the conflict be sore / between that and my blood.
enriched.full_text:
[Aside]  If I find him comforting the king, it will
stuff his suspicion more fully.--I will persevere in
my course of loyalty, though the conflict be sore
between that and my blood.
enriched.character_situation: Edmund continues his manipulation, planning to further incriminate his father Gloucester by catching him helping Lear. He coldly calculates his next move in his ambitious scheme.

enriched.quote: Tom will throw his head at them. Avaunt, you curs! / Be thy mouth or black or white, / Tooth that poisons if it bite; / Mastiff, grey-hound, mongrel grim,
enriched.full_text:
Tom will throw his head at them. Avaunt, you curs!
Be thy mouth or black or white,
Tooth that poisons if it bite;
Mastiff, grey-hound, mongrel grim,
Hound or spaniel, brach or lym,
Or bobtail tike or trundle-tail,
Tom will make them weep and wail:
For, with throwing thus my head,
Dogs leap the hatch, and all are fled.
Do de, de, de. Sessa! Come, march to wakes and
fairs and market-towns. Poor Tom, thy horn is dry.
enriched.character_situation: Edgar as Poor Tom is either confronting real or imaginary dogs, using his mad persona to ward them off. He continues his performance of insanity while expressing the isolation of his exile.

enriched.quote: Then let them anatomize Regan; see what breeds / about her heart. Is there any cause in nature that / makes these hard hearts? / You, sir, I entertain for one of my hundred; only I
enriched.full_text:
Then let them anatomize Regan; see what breeds
about her heart. Is there any cause in nature that
makes these hard hearts?
You, sir, I entertain for one of my hundred; only I
do not like the fashion of your garments: you will
say they are Persian attire: but let them be changed.
enriched.character_situation: Lear, in his madness during the storm, obsesses over his daughters' cruelty and seeks to understand the nature of their hard hearts. His mind shifts erratically between profound questions and trivial concerns.

enriched.quote: Good friend, I prithee, take him in thy arms; / I have o'erheard a plot of death upon him: / There is a litter ready; lay him in 't, / And drive towards Dover, friend, where thou shalt meet
enriched.full_text:
Good friend, I prithee, take him in thy arms;
I have o'erheard a plot of death upon him:
There is a litter ready; lay him in 't,
And drive towards Dover, friend, where thou shalt meet
Both welcome and protection. Take up thy master:
If thou shouldst dally half an hour, his life,
With thine, and all that offer to defend him,
Stand in assured loss: take up, take up;
And follow me, that will to some provision
Give thee quick conduct.
enriched.character_situation: Gloucester urgently arranges for Lear's rescue, having overheard a plot against the king's life. He risks his own safety to help Lear escape to Dover, showing loyalty despite the danger.

enriched.quote: When we our betters see bearing our woes, / We scarcely think our miseries our foes. / Who alone suffers suffers most i' the mind, / Leaving free things and happy shows behind:
enriched.full_text:
When we our betters see bearing our woes,
We scarcely think our miseries our foes.
Who alone suffers suffers most i' the mind,
Leaving free things and happy shows behind:
But then the mind much sufferance doth o'er skip,
When grief hath mates, and bearing fellowship.
How light and portable my pain seems now,
When that which makes me bend makes the king bow,
He childed as I father'd! Tom, away!
Mark the high noises; and thyself bewray,
When false opinion, whose wrong thought defiles thee,
In thy just proof, repeals and reconciles thee.
What will hap more to-night, safe 'scape the king!
Lurk, lurk.
enriched.character_situation: Edgar reflects on how witnessing Lear's suffering makes his own pain more bearable, finding comfort in shared misery. He prepares to abandon his Tom disguise when the time is right for his vindication.

enriched.quote: Leave him to my displeasure. Edmund, keep you our / sister company: the revenges we are bound to take / upon your traitorous father are not fit for your / beholding. Advise the duke, where you are going, to
enriched.full_text:
Leave him to my displeasure. Edmund, keep you our
sister company: the revenges we are bound to take
upon your traitorous father are not fit for your
beholding. Advise the duke, where you are going, to
a most festinate preparation: we are bound to the
like. Our posts shall be swift and intelligent
betwixt us. Farewell, dear sister: farewell, my
lord of Gloucester.
How now! where's the king?
enriched.character_situation: Cornwall commands Edmund to leave before they torture Gloucester, showing both authority and a twisted mercy by sparing Edmund the sight of his father's punishment. He efficiently coordinates military preparations while planning revenge.

enriched.quote: Because I would not see thy cruel nails / Pluck out his poor old eyes; nor thy fierce sister / In his anointed flesh stick boarish fangs. / The sea, with such a storm as his bare head
enriched.full_text:
Because I would not see thy cruel nails
Pluck out his poor old eyes; nor thy fierce sister
In his anointed flesh stick boarish fangs.
The sea, with such a storm as his bare head
In hell-black night endured, would have buoy'd up,
And quench'd the stelled fires:
Yet, poor old heart, he holp the heavens to rain.
If wolves had at thy gate howl'd that stern time,
Thou shouldst have said 'Good porter, turn the key,'
All cruels else subscribed: but I shall see
The winged vengeance overtake such children.
enriched.character_situation: Gloucester defiantly explains his loyalty to Lear even as he faces torture from Cornwall and Regan. He condemns their cruelty and predicts divine vengeance will punish them for their unnatural behavior.

enriched.quote: Out, treacherous villain! / Thou call'st on him that hates thee: it was he / That made the overture of thy treasons to us; / Who is too good to pity thee.
enriched.full_text:
Out, treacherous villain!
Thou call'st on him that hates thee: it was he
That made the overture of thy treasons to us;
Who is too good to pity thee.
enriched.character_situation: Regan reveals Edmund's betrayal of his father to Gloucester, showing no mercy as she condemns him. She demonstrates her ruthless nature and alliance with Edmund against her own family.

enriched.quote: Yet better thus, and known to be contemn'd, / Than still contemn'd and flatter'd. To be worst, / The lowest and most dejected thing of fortune, / Stands still in esperance, lives not in fear:
enriched.full_text:
Yet better thus, and known to be contemn'd,
Than still contemn'd and flatter'd. To be worst,
The lowest and most dejected thing of fortune,
Stands still in esperance, lives not in fear:
The lamentable change is from the best;
The worst returns to laughter. Welcome, then,
Thou unsubstantial air that I embrace!
The wretch that thou hast blown unto the worst
Owes nothing to thy blasts. But who comes here?
My father, poorly led? World, world, O world!
But that thy strange mutations make us hate thee,
Lie would not yield to age.
enriched.character_situation: Edgar, disguised as Poor Tom, reflects on his fall from grace and finds philosophical comfort in being at rock bottom. He suddenly sees his blind father being led and realizes how much worse things have become.

enriched.quote: He has some reason, else he could not beg. / I' the last night's storm I such a fellow saw; / Which made me think a man a worm: my son / Came then into my mind; and yet my mind
enriched.full_text:
He has some reason, else he could not beg.
I' the last night's storm I such a fellow saw;
Which made me think a man a worm: my son
Came then into my mind; and yet my mind
Was then scarce friends with him: I have heard
more since.
As flies to wanton boys, are we to the gods.
They kill us for their sport.
enriched.character_situation: Gloucester, now blind and broken, encounters a beggar and reflects on human suffering and his relationship with his wronged son Edgar. He expresses a dark view of the gods' indifference to human pain.

enriched.quote: Both stile and gate, horse-way and foot-path. Poor / Tom hath been scared out of his good wits: bless / thee, good man's son, from the foul fiend! five / fiends have been in poor Tom at once; of lust, as
enriched.full_text:
Both stile and gate, horse-way and foot-path. Poor
Tom hath been scared out of his good wits: bless
thee, good man's son, from the foul fiend! five
fiends have been in poor Tom at once; of lust, as
Obidicut; Hobbididence, prince of dumbness; Mahu, of
stealing; Modo, of murder; Flibbertigibbet, of
mopping and mowing, who since possesses chambermaids
and waiting-women. So, bless thee, master!
enriched.character_situation: Edgar maintains his disguise as Poor Tom, a mad beggar possessed by demons. He speaks in character about the various fiends that torment him, using madness as protection from recognition.

enriched.quote: Here, take this purse, thou whom the heavens' plagues / Have humbled to all strokes: that I am wretched / Makes thee the happier: heavens, deal so still! / Let the superfluous and lust-dieted man,
enriched.full_text:
Here, take this purse, thou whom the heavens' plagues
Have humbled to all strokes: that I am wretched
Makes thee the happier: heavens, deal so still!
Let the superfluous and lust-dieted man,
That slaves your ordinance, that will not see
Because he doth not feel, feel your power quickly;
So distribution should undo excess,
And each man have enough. Dost thou know Dover?
enriched.character_situation: Gloucester gives money to the disguised Edgar (not knowing it's his son) and reflects on social inequality. His suffering has made him more compassionate toward the poor and critical of the wealthy.

enriched.quote: Madam, within; but never man so changed. / I told him of the army that was landed; / He smiled at it: I told him you were coming: / His answer was 'The worse:' of Gloucester's treachery,
enriched.full_text:
Madam, within; but never man so changed.
I told him of the army that was landed;
He smiled at it: I told him you were coming:
His answer was 'The worse:' of Gloucester's treachery,
And of the loyal service of his son,
When I inform'd him, then he call'd me sot,
And told me I had turn'd the wrong side out:
What most he should dislike seems pleasant to him;
What like, offensive.
enriched.character_situation: Oswald reports to Goneril about Albany's strange transformation, describing how her husband now reacts positively to bad news and negatively to what should please him. Albany's moral awakening confuses the corrupt servant.

enriched.quote: [To EDMUND]  Then shall you go no further. / It is the cowish terror of his spirit, / That dares not undertake: he'll not feel wrongs / Which tie him to an answer. Our wishes on the way
enriched.full_text:
[To EDMUND]  Then shall you go no further.
It is the cowish terror of his spirit,
That dares not undertake: he'll not feel wrongs
Which tie him to an answer. Our wishes on the way
May prove effects. Back, Edmund, to my brother;
Hasten his musters and conduct his powers:
I must change arms at home, and give the distaff
Into my husband's hands. This trusty servant
Shall pass between us: ere long you are like to hear,
If you dare venture in your own behalf,
A mistress's command. Wear this; spare speech;
Decline your head: this kiss, if it durst speak,
Would stretch thy spirits up into the air:
Conceive, and fare thee well.
enriched.character_situation: Goneril dismisses Edmund with passionate promises of love and power while criticizing her husband Albany's moral stance. She plots to take military control and pursue her affair with Edmund.

enriched.quote: O Goneril! / You are not worth the dust which the rude wind / Blows in your face. I fear your disposition: / That nature, which contemns its origin,
enriched.full_text:
O Goneril!
You are not worth the dust which the rude wind
Blows in your face. I fear your disposition:
That nature, which contemns its origin,
Cannot be border'd certain in itself;
She that herself will sliver and disbranch
From her material sap, perforce must wither
And come to deadly use.
enriched.character_situation: Albany confronts his wife Goneril with moral outrage, condemning her unnatural behavior toward her father. He warns that those who betray family bonds will ultimately destroy themselves.

enriched.quote: Wisdom and goodness to the vile seem vile: / Filths savour but themselves. What have you done? / Tigers, not daughters, what have you perform'd? / A father, and a gracious aged man,
enriched.full_text:
Wisdom and goodness to the vile seem vile:
Filths savour but themselves. What have you done?
Tigers, not daughters, what have you perform'd?
A father, and a gracious aged man,
Whose reverence even the head-lugg'd bear would lick,
Most barbarous, most degenerate! have you madded.
Could my good brother suffer you to do it?
A man, a prince, by him so benefited!
If that the heavens do not their visible spirits
Send quickly down to tame these vile offences,
It will come,
Humanity must perforce prey on itself,
Like monsters of the deep.
enriched.character_situation: Albany continues his moral condemnation of Goneril and Regan's treatment of Lear, warning that without divine justice, humanity will descend into chaos. He expresses horror at their betrayal of their father and benefactor.

enriched.quote: Milk-liver'd man! / That bear'st a cheek for blows, a head for wrongs; / Who hast not in thy brows an eye discerning / Thine honour from thy suffering; that not know'st
enriched.character_situation: Goneril attacks Albany's moral stance as cowardice, mocking his reluctance to take aggressive action against their enemies. She criticizes his compassion and calls him weak for not preparing for war against the invading French forces.

enriched.quote: Not to a rage: patience and sorrow strove / Who should express her goodliest. You have seen / Sunshine and rain at once: her smiles and tears / Were like a better way: those happy smilets,
enriched.full_text:
Not to a rage: patience and sorrow strove
Who should express her goodliest. You have seen
Sunshine and rain at once: her smiles and tears
Were like a better way: those happy smilets,
That play'd on her ripe lip, seem'd not to know
What guests were in her eyes; which parted thence,
As pearls from diamonds dropp'd. In brief,
Sorrow would be a rarity most beloved,
If all could so become it.
enriched.character_situation: A gentleman describes Cordelia's beautiful and controlled grief upon learning of her father's suffering. He portrays her as the embodiment of virtue, showing both sorrow and patience simultaneously in an almost ethereal manner.

enriched.quote: 'Faith, once or twice she heaved the name of 'father' / Pantingly forth, as if it press'd her heart: / Cried 'Sisters! sisters! Shame of ladies! sisters! / Kent! father! sisters! What, i' the storm? i' the night?
enriched.full_text:
'Faith, once or twice she heaved the name of 'father'
Pantingly forth, as if it press'd her heart:
Cried 'Sisters! sisters! Shame of ladies! sisters!
Kent! father! sisters! What, i' the storm? i' the night?
Let pity not be believed!' There she shook
The holy water from her heavenly eyes,
And clamour moisten'd: then away she started
To deal with grief alone.
enriched.character_situation: The Gentleman is describing Cordelia's emotional breakdown as she learns of her father's suffering in the storm. He witnesses her profound grief and shame over her sisters' cruelty.

enriched.quote: Alack, 'tis he: why, he was met even now / As mad as the vex'd sea; singing aloud; / Crown'd with rank fumiter and furrow-weeds, / With bur-docks, hemlock, nettles, cuckoo-flowers,
enriched.full_text:
Alack, 'tis he: why, he was met even now
As mad as the vex'd sea; singing aloud;
Crown'd with rank fumiter and furrow-weeds,
With bur-docks, hemlock, nettles, cuckoo-flowers,
Darnel, and all the idle weeds that grow
In our sustaining corn. A century send forth;
Search every acre in the high-grown field,
And bring him to our eye.
What can man's wisdom
In the restoring his bereaved sense?
He that helps him take all my outward worth.
enriched.character_situation: Cordelia discovers her father Lear in a state of complete madness, crowned with weeds. She desperately seeks to restore his sanity and offers everything she has to help him.

enriched.quote: 'Tis known before; our preparation stands / In expectation of them. O dear father, / It is thy business that I go about; / Therefore great France
enriched.full_text:
'Tis known before; our preparation stands
In expectation of them. O dear father,
It is thy business that I go about;
Therefore great France
My mourning and important tears hath pitied.
No blown ambition doth our arms incite,
But love, dear love, and our aged father's right:
Soon may I hear and see him!
enriched.character_situation: Cordelia explains her return to Britain with French forces, motivated purely by love for her father rather than political ambition. She prepares for battle to restore Lear's rightful position.

enriched.quote: I speak in understanding; you are; I know't: / Therefore I do advise you, take this note: / My lord is dead; Edmund and I have talk'd; / And more convenient is he for my hand
enriched.full_text:
I speak in understanding; you are; I know't:
Therefore I do advise you, take this note:
My lord is dead; Edmund and I have talk'd;
And more convenient is he for my hand
Than for your lady's: you may gather more.
If you do find him, pray you, give him this;
And when your mistress hears thus much from you,
I pray, desire her call her wisdom to her.
So, fare you well.
If you do chance to hear of that blind traitor,
Preferment falls on him that cuts him off.
enriched.character_situation: Regan coldly manipulates Oswald, claiming Edmund as her own while her husband lies dead. She shows ruthless ambition and offers a reward for Gloucester's murder.

enriched.quote: Come on, sir; here's the place: stand still. How fearful / And dizzy 'tis, to cast one's eyes so low! / The crows and choughs that wing the midway air / Show scarce so gross as beetles: half way down
enriched.full_text:
Come on, sir; here's the place: stand still. How fearful
And dizzy 'tis, to cast one's eyes so low!
The crows and choughs that wing the midway air
Show scarce so gross as beetles: half way down
Hangs one that gathers samphire, dreadful trade!
Methinks he seems no bigger than his head:
The fishermen, that walk upon the beach,
Appear like mice; and yond tall anchoring bark,
Diminish'd to her cock; her cock, a buoy
Almost too small for sight: the murmuring surge,
That on the unnumber'd idle pebbles chafes,
Cannot be heard so high. I'll look no more;
Lest my brain turn, and the deficient sight
Topple down headlong.
enriched.character_situation: Edgar, disguised as Poor Tom, deceives his suicidal father Gloucester by describing an imaginary cliff edge. He attempts to prevent his father's suicide through elaborate deception.

enriched.quote: [Kneeling]  O you mighty gods! / This world I do renounce, and, in your sights, / Shake patiently my great affliction off: / If I could bear it longer, and not fall
enriched.full_text:
[Kneeling]  O you mighty gods!
This world I do renounce, and, in your sights,
Shake patiently my great affliction off:
If I could bear it longer, and not fall
To quarrel with your great opposeless wills,
My snuff and loathed part of nature should
Burn itself out. If Edgar live, O, bless him!
Now, fellow, fare thee well.
enriched.character_situation: Gloucester, believing he stands at Dover cliff, prepares for suicide to end his suffering. He renounces the world and blesses his son Edgar before attempting to leap to his death.

enriched.quote: Gone, sir: farewell. / And yet I know not how conceit may rob / The treasury of life, when life itself / Yields to the theft: had he been where he thought,
enriched.full_text:
Gone, sir: farewell.
And yet I know not how conceit may rob
The treasury of life, when life itself
Yields to the theft: had he been where he thought,
By this, had thought been past. Alive or dead?
Ho, you sir! friend! Hear you, sir! speak!
Thus might he pass indeed: yet he revives.
What are you, sir?
enriched.character_situation: Edgar reflects on his father's failed suicide attempt and the power of imagination over reality. He revives the unconscious Gloucester and prepares to continue his deception.

enriched.quote: Nature's above art in that respect. There's your / press-money. That fellow handles his bow like a / crow-keeper: draw me a clothier's yard. Look, / look, a mouse! Peace, peace; this piece of toasted
enriched.full_text:
Nature's above art in that respect. There's your
press-money. That fellow handles his bow like a
crow-keeper: draw me a clothier's yard. Look,
look, a mouse! Peace, peace; this piece of toasted
cheese will do 't. There's my gauntlet; I'll prove
it on a giant. Bring up the brown bills. O, well
flown, bird! i' the clout, i' the clout: hewgh!
Give the word.
enriched.character_situation: Lear, in his madness, imagines he is commanding troops and engaging in various military activities. His mind creates a fantasy world of battles and archery.

enriched.quote: Ha! Goneril, with a white beard! They flattered / me like a dog; and told me I had white hairs in my / beard ere the black ones were there. To say 'ay' / and 'no' to every thing that I said!--'Ay' and 'no'
enriched.full_text:
Ha! Goneril, with a white beard! They flattered
me like a dog; and told me I had white hairs in my
beard ere the black ones were there. To say 'ay'
and 'no' to every thing that I said!--'Ay' and 'no'
too was no good divinity. When the rain came to
wet me once, and the wind to make me chatter; when
the thunder would not peace at my bidding; there I
found 'em, there I smelt 'em out. Go to, they are
not men o' their words: they told me I was every
thing; 'tis a lie, I am not ague-proof.
enriched.character_situation: Lear, still mad, reflects bitterly on how his courtiers flattered him when he had power but abandoned him when he faced the storm's harsh reality. He realizes their false loyalty.

enriched.quote: Ay, every inch a king: / When I do stare, see how the subject quakes. / I pardon that man's life. What was thy cause? Adultery? / Thou shalt not die: die for adultery! No:
enriched.full_text:
Ay, every inch a king:
When I do stare, see how the subject quakes.
I pardon that man's life. What was thy cause? Adultery?
Thou shalt not die: die for adultery! No:
The wren goes to 't, and the small gilded fly
Does lecher in my sight.
Let copulation thrive; for Gloucester's bastard son
Was kinder to his father than my daughters
Got 'tween the lawful sheets.
To 't, luxury, pell-mell! for I lack soldiers.
Behold yond simpering dame,
Whose face between her forks presages snow;
That minces virtue, and does shake the head
To hear of pleasure's name;
The fitchew, nor the soiled horse, goes to 't
With a more riotous appetite.
Down from the waist they are Centaurs,
Though women all above:
But to the girdle do the gods inherit,
Beneath is all the fiends';
There's hell, there's darkness, there's the
sulphurous pit,
Burning, scalding, stench, consumption; fie,
fie, fie! pah, pah! Give me an ounce of civet,
good apothecary, to sweeten my imagination:
there's money for thee.
enriched.character_situation: Lear, in his madness, delivers a powerful tirade about sexuality, corruption, and the nature of women, comparing his bastard son-in-law favorably to his legitimate daughters. He sees through social hypocrisy with mad clarity.

enriched.quote: O, ho, are you there with me? No eyes in your / head, nor no money in your purse? Your eyes are in / a heavy case, your purse in a light; yet you see how / this world goes.
enriched.full_text:
O, ho, are you there with me? No eyes in your
head, nor no money in your purse? Your eyes are in
a heavy case, your purse in a light; yet you see how
this world goes.
enriched.character_situation: Lear, in his madness, encounters the blind Gloucester and makes bitter observations about their shared loss of sight and fortune.

enriched.quote: What, art mad? A man may see how this world goes / with no eyes. Look with thine ears: see how yond / justice rails upon yond simple thief. Hark, in / thine ear: change places; and, handy-dandy, which
enriched.full_text:
What, art mad? A man may see how this world goes
with no eyes. Look with thine ears: see how yond
justice rails upon yond simple thief. Hark, in
thine ear: change places; and, handy-dandy, which
is the justice, which is the thief? Thou hast seen
a farmer's dog bark at a beggar?
enriched.character_situation: Lear philosophically questions the nature of justice and authority, suggesting that moral corruption pervades all levels of society.

enriched.quote: And the creature run from the cur? There thou / mightst behold the great image of authority: a / dog's obeyed in office. / Thou rascal beadle, hold thy bloody hand!
enriched.full_text:
And the creature run from the cur? There thou
mightst behold the great image of authority: a
dog's obeyed in office.
Thou rascal beadle, hold thy bloody hand!
Why dost thou lash that whore? Strip thine own back;
Thou hotly lust'st to use her in that kind
For which thou whipp'st her. The usurer hangs the cozener.
Through tatter'd clothes small vices do appear;
Robes and furr'd gowns hide all. Plate sin with gold,
And the strong lance of justice hurtless breaks:
Arm it in rags, a pigmy's straw does pierce it.
None does offend, none, I say, none; I'll able 'em:
Take that of me, my friend, who have the power
To seal the accuser's lips. Get thee glass eyes;
And like a scurvy politician, seem
To see the things thou dost not. Now, now, now, now:
Pull off my boots: harder, harder: so.
enriched.character_situation: Lear delivers a scathing critique of social hypocrisy and corruption, exposing how authority masks vice while poverty exposes minor faults.

enriched.quote: If thou wilt weep my fortunes, take my eyes. / I know thee well enough; thy name is Gloucester: / Thou must be patient; we came crying hither: / Thou know'st, the first time that we smell the air,
enriched.full_text:
If thou wilt weep my fortunes, take my eyes.
I know thee well enough; thy name is Gloucester:
Thou must be patient; we came crying hither:
Thou know'st, the first time that we smell the air,
We wawl and cry. I will preach to thee: mark.
enriched.character_situation: Lear recognizes Gloucester and reflects on the universal human condition of suffering from birth.

enriched.quote: No rescue? What, a prisoner? I am even / The natural fool of fortune. Use me well; / You shall have ransom. Let me have surgeons; / I am cut to the brains.
enriched.character_situation: Lear realizes he's been captured and accepts his fate as fortune's victim, desperately seeking medical attention for his wounds.

enriched.quote: Sit you down, father; rest you / Let's see these pockets: the letters that he speaks of / May be my friends. He's dead; I am only sorry / He had no other death's-man. Let us see:
enriched.full_text:
Sit you down, father; rest you
Let's see these pockets: the letters that he speaks of
May be my friends. He's dead; I am only sorry
He had no other death's-man. Let us see:
Leave, gentle wax; and, manners, blame us not:
To know our enemies' minds, we'ld rip their hearts;
Their papers, is more lawful.
'Let our reciprocal vows be remembered. You have
many opportunities to cut him off: if your will
want not, time and place will be fruitfully offered.
There is nothing done, if he return the conqueror:
then am I the prisoner, and his bed my goal; from
the loathed warmth whereof deliver me, and supply
the place for your labour.
'Your--wife, so I would say--
'Affectionate servant,
'GONERIL.'
O undistinguish'd space of woman's will!
A plot upon her virtuous husband's life;
And the exchange my brother! Here, in the sands,
Thee I'll rake up, the post unsanctified
Of murderous lechers: and in the mature time
With this ungracious paper strike the sight
Of the death practised duke: for him 'tis well
That of thy death and business I can tell.
enriched.character_situation: Edgar discovers Goneril's letter plotting Edmund's assassination of Albany, giving him crucial evidence to expose the conspiracy.

enriched.quote: Had you not been their father, these white flakes / Had challenged pity of them. Was this a face / To be opposed against the warring winds? / To stand against the deep dread-bolted thunder?
enriched.full_text:
Had you not been their father, these white flakes
Had challenged pity of them. Was this a face
To be opposed against the warring winds?
To stand against the deep dread-bolted thunder?
In the most terrible and nimble stroke
Of quick, cross lightning? to watch--poor perdu!--
With this thin helm? Mine enemy's dog,
Though he had bit me, should have stood that night
Against my fire; and wast thou fain, poor father,
To hovel thee with swine, and rogues forlorn,
In short and musty straw? Alack, alack!
'Tis wonder that thy life and wits at once
Had not concluded all. He wakes; speak to him.
enriched.character_situation: Cordelia tenderly laments her father's suffering during the storm, expressing grief and compassion for his mistreatment.

enriched.quote: Pray, do not mock me: / I am a very foolish fond old man, / Fourscore and upward, not an hour more nor less; / And, to deal plainly,
enriched.full_text:
Pray, do not mock me:
I am a very foolish fond old man,
Fourscore and upward, not an hour more nor less;
And, to deal plainly,
I fear I am not in my perfect mind.
Methinks I should know you, and know this man;
Yet I am doubtful for I am mainly ignorant
What place this is; and all the skill I have
Remembers not these garments; nor I know not
Where I did lodge last night. Do not laugh at me;
For, as I am a man, I think this lady
To be my child Cordelia.
enriched.character_situation: Lear awakens from his madness, confused and vulnerable, slowly recognizing Cordelia with humility and uncertainty about his mental state.

enriched.quote: Know of the duke if his last purpose hold, / Or whether since he is advised by aught / To change the course: he's full of alteration / And self-reproving: bring his constant pleasure.
enriched.full_text:
Know of the duke if his last purpose hold,
Or whether since he is advised by aught
To change the course: he's full of alteration
And self-reproving: bring his constant pleasure.
enriched.character_situation: Edmund gives tactical orders about Albany's military intentions, noting the duke's indecisiveness and tendency toward self-doubt.

enriched.quote: Our very loving sister, well be-met. / Sir, this I hear; the king is come to his daughter, / With others whom the rigor of our state / Forced to cry out. Where I could not be honest,
enriched.full_text:
Our very loving sister, well be-met.
Sir, this I hear; the king is come to his daughter,
With others whom the rigor of our state
Forced to cry out. Where I could not be honest,
I never yet was valiant: for this business,
It toucheth us, as France invades our land,
Not bolds the king, with others, whom, I fear,
Most just and heavy causes make oppose.
enriched.character_situation: Albany greets Goneril while explaining his conflicted position about fighting the French invasion that supports Lear's just cause.

enriched.quote: To both these sisters have I sworn my love; / Each jealous of the other, as the stung / Are of the adder. Which of them shall I take? / Both? one? or neither? Neither can be enjoy'd,
enriched.full_text:
To both these sisters have I sworn my love;
Each jealous of the other, as the stung
Are of the adder. Which of them shall I take?
Both? one? or neither? Neither can be enjoy'd,
If both remain alive: to take the widow
Exasperates, makes mad her sister Goneril;
And hardly shall I carry out my side,
Her husband being alive. Now then we'll use
His countenance for the battle; which being done,
Let her who would be rid of him devise
His speedy taking off. As for the mercy
Which he intends to Lear and to Cordelia,
The battle done, and they within our power,
Shall never see his pardon; for my state
Stands on me to defend, not to debate.
enriched.character_situation: Edmund coldly calculates how to manipulate both Goneril and Regan's love for him while plotting to eliminate his rivals. He strategically plans to use Albany in battle then have him killed, and to prevent mercy for Lear and Cordelia.

enriched.quote: No, no, no, no! Come, let's away to prison: / We two alone will sing like birds i' the cage: / When thou dost ask me blessing, I'll kneel down, / And ask of thee forgiveness: so we'll live,
enriched.full_text:
No, no, no, no! Come, let's away to prison:
We two alone will sing like birds i' the cage:
When thou dost ask me blessing, I'll kneel down,
And ask of thee forgiveness: so we'll live,
And pray, and sing, and tell old tales, and laugh
At gilded butterflies, and hear poor rogues
Talk of court news; and we'll talk with them too,
Who loses and who wins; who's in, who's out;
And take upon's the mystery of things,
As if we were God's spies: and we'll wear out,
In a wall'd prison, packs and sects of great ones,
That ebb and flow by the moon.
enriched.character_situation: Lear, facing imprisonment with Cordelia, transforms his despair into a vision of peaceful reconciliation. He imagines their captivity as a blessed retreat from the corrupt world where they can find forgiveness and simple joy together.

enriched.quote: Come hither, captain; hark. / Take thou this note; / go follow them to prison: / One step I have advanced thee; if thou dost
enriched.full_text:
Come hither, captain; hark.
Take thou this note;
go follow them to prison:
One step I have advanced thee; if thou dost
As this instructs thee, thou dost make thy way
To noble fortunes: know thou this, that men
Are as the time is: to be tender-minded
Does not become a sword: thy great employment
Will not bear question; either say thou'lt do 't,
Or thrive by other means.
enriched.character_situation: Edmund secretly orders a captain to carry out murderous instructions, likely against Lear and Cordelia. He cynically justifies ruthlessness as necessary for advancement and survival in harsh times.

enriched.quote: Sir, I thought it fit / To send the old and miserable king / To some retention and appointed guard; / Whose age has charms in it, whose title more,
enriched.full_text:
Sir, I thought it fit
To send the old and miserable king
To some retention and appointed guard;
Whose age has charms in it, whose title more,
To pluck the common bosom on his side,
An turn our impress'd lances in our eyes
Which do command them. With him I sent the queen;
My reason all the same; and they are ready
To-morrow, or at further space, to appear
Where you shall hold your session. At this time
We sweat and bleed: the friend hath lost his friend;
And the best quarrels, in the heat, are cursed
By those that feel their sharpness:
The question of Cordelia and her father
Requires a fitter place.
enriched.character_situation: Edmund justifies his imprisonment of Lear and Cordelia by arguing they pose a political threat. He presents himself as pragmatic while concealing his murderous intentions behind reasonable-sounding strategic concerns.

enriched.quote: Stay yet; hear reason. Edmund, I arrest thee / On capital treason; and, in thine attaint, / This gilded serpent / For your claim, fair sister,
